A very green fragrance and the scent profile is pleasant

It is an easy to enjoy and my friends have said they like it too.

This is a summer fresh perfume and for the daytime

Sprays 2-5 (Depends on the heat and day)
Price 5/10 (not ideal)
Longevity 6/10
Sillage 5/10

7/10
For a fresh summer fragrance this is a good fragrance despite it being simple and a little on the boring side price is a downside tho

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I defenetly think this is not worth the price for what you get at all after owning it for some months. It’s just a green freshie, thats all. There are better alternatives. Does’nt perform that good also

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Rosemary, cedar, and a ton of barbershop style tonka despite that not being a listed note. Definitely agree with the comparison to the OG code. Love it.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I love wearing this at home!

Every five days I do my grooming routine and use it afterward to feel clean, classy, and masculine. It is a timeless "old school" scent, pretty basic but it has that Italian vibe that I like. Fragrances along this one that make me feel the same are Dior Homme Sport or Cologne, Versace Pour Homme, Xerjoff Nio, Roja Parfums Elysium, and MFK Masculine Pluriel or 724.

Nex try will be Bergamotto di Calabria!

Longevity is quite iffy, but if you overspray on cotton clothes it will stay a long time with a low projection. I usually get 3-4 hours on my skin and like 24 hours on my shirt with 8 sprays haha

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: In my opinion this has a bit of Luna Rossa Sport, and a bit of Armani Code, but it's done better than both. Going to be my next pickup I think.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Some sort of le male and sauvage elixir mix?

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Longevity and projection isn’t great but wow this is lovely

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Got it off a discounter (Jomashop) for a price way below retail, which is think is way better than buying it for its retail price. This isn’t sponsored btw I just want to tell you guys that you NEVER buy frags retail price unless they don’t allow discounters (Chanel, LV, City Rhythm, etc.) anyways, this is a great everyday safe green and spicy scent. It IS an EDC which is TERRIBLE but its longevity isn’t too bad, about 4-5 hours without letting it macerate (FRAGS ARE ALWAYS BETTER WHEN LEFT TO MACERATE FOR A COUPLE WEEKS). It’s a smell you can’t really hate and it’s VERY VERY basic but also somewhat fancy. I’d say get it if you want a good summer citrusy “fresh spicy” scent (what I wanted).

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I thought I'd bought a sample of the original CLUB, but I realized I'd bought another fragrance I was used to.

It has the same herbaceous vibe that is a more citrusy, woody scent, still with the famous menthol note. The same occasions and versatility as the original. Last 5 hours (shame) and a fair projection.

According to my rating system, it's a 7/10 but I give -2 penalties for acting like a "snake in the grass" (no pun intended) to fool people: 5/10.

Try before you buy

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I've smelled this before but wasn't impressed so I never bothered testing it until today. I'm afraid ADP seems to be losing their direction since around 2020 and this is a good example of that. This smells like your average musky cedar designer and the comparisons to Armani Code are justified. ADP has always been more about classics and some modern stuff outside of the signatures of the sun line, but this just seems like a lazy.

Is it pleasant? Sure. Does it have any personality? Not much. It's very plain, innofensive, generic and boring. It smells like something you'd pick up at the mall or Walgreens from a low level to mid tier designer house. Armani Code is better than this, and the latest Armani Code Parfum is way better than this, in my opinion.
---------------------------------------------------------
Scent 50/100
Performance TBD

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I loved the original Colonia Club and its wonderfully fresh minty summer veranda with gin tonics and cocktails but this Colonia C.L.U.B. reformulation -whilst perfectly pleasant - has removed that minty freshness and lost that *love!* element.

Shame, really.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: It’s nice, it really is, but the price is not worth it to me. It’s a perfect fresh “out-of-the-shower” type fragrance, but really nothing more than that. You can buy fragrances that will cost you 1/5 of this and smell equally as good, trust me!

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
One of my favourite Acqua Di Parmas and I think I know why.
I am a big fan of Chanel Allure Homme Sport (edt and eau extreme) and theres something about this fragrance that reminds me of the allure line.
I think its the citrus, creamy and woody accords that are giving me that vibe.
What do you guys think?

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I like this fragrance a lot. To me this smells like a country club mixed with a citrusy element, and I think this is a relatively safe and mass-appealing fragrance. Performance and price are the biggest drawbacks when it comes to this, but if somehow those aren't an issue, this is great.

side note: good atomizer

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
one of the few fragrances out there that have an almost euphoric quality to me. though as much as i love it, i want to snatch it up for a good price because of how fleeting and weak it is. even £80 im not fond of paying. reminds me a tad bit of prada lhomme.

also i agree with the comment below- when i first found out about this fragrance (about a year and a half ago) the reviews were brutal, i suppose because it was a new version of an already existing fragrance (similar to the hate dior homme 2020 got).

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Glad to see some more positive reviews of this roll in.

The opening is quite fresh and comes across almost minty with the shiso.

Not a loud fragrance but don’t be scared of the EDC concentration as I am getting a respectable 6-7 hours of performance with around 1.5 of noticeable push before getting closer.

Fantastic - Simple Done Right. Office friendly and welcomed apparently as I got asked what I was wearing as it smelled so good. Woman pleaser.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Love the scent, too pricey though. Reminds me of a mix between Prada Luna Rossa Ocean EDT and the EDP.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: The moment I smelt it, I fell in love. This fragrance smells professional and rich, appropriate in any season or setting. 10/10.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Reading the reviews and also seeing this reduced in Harrods, I can’t believe this fragrance gets the hate it does. Although to some it may be “generic” and “disappointing”, to be put simply, you can’t go wrong with it. It’s simple, nice smelling and gentlemen like.

At first it’s a spicy citrus pepper which then dies down into a more barbershop type fragrance with the rosemary and cedar. Not to mention its longevity is very good, having sprayed it in the morning and being able to smell it on my clothes the next day, one should be able to smell it the whole day. However, its projection may let it down a little, depending on the persons skin (at least with mine), I find that it can turn into a skin fragrance after hours of wearing. Which is why I’d recommend a travel atomizer just to boost projection later in the day. Yet, for the price you can find it for, either at online discounters, duty free or discounted in store. This is a no brainer if you enjoy ADP and barbershop type fragrances.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Another bright barbershop fragrance that’s right in my wheelhouse. Citrusy in the open with some Rosemary in the background and dries down to a powderish,fresh gentlemanly scent. I got pretty good performance from this fragrance. I kept getting whiffs from it throughout the day and I could still smell it at bed time. I can’t wait to wear it in the warmer months.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The only thing this fragrance will offend is your wallet. This may be the cheapest smelling fragrance from their lineup.


Rather disappointing.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Shower gel type fragrance, very outdated and basic. The scent is a 6/10 and this is not a fragrance that I would recommend checking out.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Extremely fresh and pleasant. To me this is in the same family as the original Prada Luna Rossa with even better quality and added green with the shiso. Not that they smell exactly alike, about 60-70% similar with the airy freshness with a touch of sweetness to round it out, then add more grassy type green than Luna Rossa. This stuff is absolutely beautiful and fresh like you just got out of the shower. Scent to me is 9/10 and performance is on par with most EDTs even though this is an EDC. It's a love for me.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia C.L.U.B. is a disappointing scent, a rare miss for Acqua di Parma. Having also tested Colonia Futura today, an excellent fougère, there is no comparison. C.L.U.B. is ultimately a flat, one-dimensional ambroxan bomb. The opening is briefly in keeping with AcP's aromatic colognes, but then the ambroxan hits.

On initial spray, C.L.U.B is a clean, fresh citrus scent with a slightly sour green undertone. This doesn't last long before the ambroxan creeps in and takes over. Ambroxan can work well in perfumery as a fixative, or can add interest when restrained. However, one of my pet hates is a heavy, grey cloud of ambroxan overpowering a scent. I find it headache-inducing, and that is the case here.

The ambroxan phase of C.L.U.B. is an unpleasantly metallic, grey cloud. Slightly woody and increasingly musky, none of the listed notes are evident after a time, except a hint of synthetic cedar. The ambroxan lingers. Sillage and longevity are moderate.

A masculine-leaning single-note ambroxan scent after the opening, I dislike this. Why anyone would choose this scent from AdP is hard to fathom. 1/5.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I think this is really nice! Lasts surprisingly long on me. I sprayed it before bed just to test it, and can smell it next morning relatively easily. Not groundbreaking by any means scent wise, but totally likable.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
“Comparisons are odorous.” Is it green? Is it blue? Is it old guy or trend jumper? Doesn’t matter. And what’s in a name?

This is a pleasing fresh warm weather scent. Opens with citrus and bergamot up front with a bit of peppery bite. Relaxes into a minty basil whiff of shiso with AdP dna quality lurking underneath, a hint of powder and then settles into musky cedar. Versatile. Makes for a nice daily driver.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I love the smell of this but… what the hell did they do to the original… this is definitely a club fragrance now. Insane projection and sillage, very fresh out of the shower type vibe. Has no business being associated with green fragrances. Maybe I’ll pick this up from a discounter but I’m the meantime I will enjoy the OG

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I really don't like this. It's stereotypically cologney with an overbearing cedarwood note that makes it hard to appreciate the nice botanical bouquet underneath. The cedar is strong enough to give me a headache, and boy does it last - many hours after application, after a shower where I tried to remove the scent with soap, I rubbed my hand on the spot where I'd applied it, and there it was.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Clean, crisp, out of the shower type scent. Office friendly every day signature stuff.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Their best offering, I think. Smells like a rich, old European guy

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Fresh clean opening with citrus notes and a hint of peppers. The spiciness here is not overwhelming, so it is still a quite summery scent. You can already get some herby woody smell from rosemary. After about one hour, I get this green note, not sure this is how shiso smells like.
The drydown is nothing but generic, reminds me of dozens of perfumes with cedar in the base note.
In general it smells pleasant, suitable for summer and appropriate for office. However, it's kinda a disappointment when you know it's AdP.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This smells amazing! This is the best cologne-smelling fragrance I've smelled since I have been in the game (only a year, but I've smelled a lot of scents). I love how fresh, slightly minty, and spicy this smells. It comes together nicely and smells intense. It's ever so slightly sharp but doesn't bother my nose. What's really good about this is that is performs constantly at least in the first one or two hours. I cannot speak for it's longevity for now but in the future I will make an edit for this review that will speak more about how long this lasts and performs. This is such an awesome smelling scent.

Update: I doused myself with this for a day and it smells good, but also basic. I'm switching from love to it's ok. This scent does travel far if the air allows, but I don't believe that it will travel too far in still air. It lasts long enough. About 6 hours.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I bought it thinking it was a new version of the Club which I love. But it has nothing to do with that one. I't a freshy, clean, out of the shower, unisex, cologne. It absolutely lacks of the Italian-gentleman touch the Club (without points) used to have.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Absolute masterpiece of a fragrance in my opinion. It’s on the blue/green side with a super clean smell to it and will not choke anyone out but still lasts all day. Could easily be a signature scent as it is very versatile and easy to wear. Appropriate for high schoolers if they want to mask the smell of their bo after gym class, business men in the office, or mature gentleman if they want to smell to part.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: A flat generic masculine cologne to me. I've smelt this DNA countless times in the designer realm and this doesn't add to the Colonia line from AdP. A big disappointment in my books. Stick to the original Colonia or the Essenza.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I haven’t decided what I feel about it yet…

The top notes are lovely- fresh and clean but after 1 hour it feels a little to sweet for my taste :/

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Love the smell. I wished the smell could last longer and greater projection.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: nauseous kinda smell

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
What really got me excited with this one is the shiso in the ingredients. ADP’s Colonia C.L.U.B. reminds you of simpler fun times - day in the sun. Bright citrus and fresh with hints of spice and a bold woody base. Its drydown for me is the winner.

Perfect for a full day’s wear and very office friendly.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Fresh citrus aromatic. Sharp citruses, peppers, and green herbal rosemary burst from my skin but in a very smoothed out and airy fashion, all over a light woody base.

No bias on my part, I know nothing of the original Club (or many other AdP fragrances for that matter), but I find this quite pleasant and extremely well-balanced. The citrus and spices and greens and woods all play an equal role, everything is seamlessly blended together, and it sits smack dab in the middle of sweet and bitter. Performance is surprisingly decent for me with moderate projection for ~2hr, longevity 12hr+.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I get nearly the same fragrance as Colonia Pura but with the aldehydes removed making it just boring. It's like the bare minimum of a fragrance which is why I think it reminds reviewers of a wide range of different scents. Total head scratcher of a release. The only good thing I can say here is that it doesn't smell "bad." It doesn’t smell like much of anything in fact. Then there’s the name and we've reached a level of mind boggling seldom seen.

Rating - 5/10

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: No resemblance to any Colonia. This should have been from the Blue line.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is literally Armani code fraiched-up, wich is not a bad smell at all!
Take code and dial down the heavier parts and add a spalsh of greenery to the mix - voilà!

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I found this quite disappointing. Not full bottle worthy in my opinion. There are much better offerings from Acqua Di Parma. The original Colonia Club for a start is miles ahead of this. I don't know what they were thinking here but C.L.U.B. is just sad.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Overpriced, ambroxan bomb. Generic as it gets. It is a shame this junk was released by the once excellent Acqua di Parma brand.

Avoid.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I tried this fragrance in Bluemercury today, completely unbiased as I didn't even know it was a new release until after I smelled it. My initial thought is that it was designed to be a more mass-appealing scent than some of the others I tested while I was there. I agree that this is ADP's entry into the "blue" fragrance world. And if someone smelling this is not crazily into fragrances, I can imagine this would be a nice, casual, summer scent that is versatile and will draw compliments without creating a harsh scent cloud.
I think this particular fragrance gets a lot of hate for differentiating from the original Colonia Club 2015. However, by itself, I still think it is a pleasant fragrance that I will be adding to my collection when it hits discounters (which, having seen its response from the public, it will).
Also, keep in mind this is an EDC, so the projection and longevity aren't going to be as prominent as another blue, such as Eros (which is quite strong). But I find the freshness of this fragrance to be nice, and still noticeable without being overbearing. This would be a great fragrance for teenagers who want to smell good from March through early September. Not exactly the most unique, but it's not inoffensive whatsoever. This is something that you can blind buy if you want to smell similar to other popular blues. Just wait until it comes to FragranceX or FragranceNet!!

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is nice. I'm not familiar with the original Colonia Club so I'm not sure how it compares. The first thing that I thought when I smelled this is that it is more of a classic scent that smells green with a hint of freshness. It smells older, mature, and masculine. I also get some kind of a powdery note.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
You know when people call a fragrance “shower gel”-y? I don’t know if I truly understood that until smelling this. I’ve never smelled a fragrance that smells more like a generic men’s shower gel in my life. It has zero character whatsoever. Honestly, this does not smell like it’s made by Acqua Di Parma (one of my favourite houses), this smells like it’s made by Axe/Lynx.

Acqua Di Parma I still love you because of many of your amazing scents (some of which rank among my favourites of all time)... but please don’t let this be the new direction you’re going in. There are ways of making a scent mass pleasing without making it this lifeless...

P.s. The original Colonia Club was a gorgeous fragrance, definitely one of the best from the house. Such a shame to see it go.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I like this. I wasn’t even aware of this release until I went to buy some stuff from the barbiere range. I wasn’t going to try given the previous club (which I owned) was too minty and while cooling had an almost burning sensation. But I did.

This one morphs from a real freshy to start with the bergamot and reminds me of a toned down of the limited edition la spugnatura and then settles into a lovely light woody skin scent after about 3 hours. The longevity on this is great. It’s very pleasant and I’m very much looking forward to wearing this on a hot day or warm evening for dinner on a terrace.

ADP is a great house, and there are classics like Essenza that I keep coming back to. On this one, and unlike the pura that was nice but not so interesting, or the futura that was just too herbacious, they got the balance here really spot on. The shiso makes this really Interesting. The pepper just right, and the dry down of woods and light musk being comforting but also leaves me feeling confident.

I just ran out of essenza and was going to refill, but this one made me go for a detour. I’ll let you know how I get on, but a few days in I’m enjoying it very much.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: A lovely addition to the Acqua di Parma Colonia lineup. I didn’t care for the original Club much, but this new version is wonderfully light and interesting enough with the minty Shiso note. The drydown has a clean, aromatic and soft light green vibe that has better longevity than I expected, perhaps thanks to some aromachemicals which luckily don’t dominate. It has a more youthful feel to it, a departure from most of the other Colonia’s in the range and this is a good thing, targeting a younger demographic keeps a brand current (apparent in the marketing and promo material for this one) but there’s still plenty of choice for those “old schoolers”. Beautifully blended as with all AdP’s. Very much looking forward to wearing this in warm weather and passing favour with the cool kids!

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Just a first impression, but might be worth writing as there are so few full reviews of this:

C.L.U.B. opens like Bergamotto or other nice AdP bergamot openings. At this stage I thought this might be a great new summer freshie.

After the opening it goes green and aromatic. At this stage I thought it does share something with the green original Club. But this is sweeter.

2h later. I think I smell the rosemary and the shiso. It's too sweet for my tastes now.

4 h later, oh, it's taken another turn. It's clearly woody now. Like a basic blue fragrance drydown, not bad, basic nice.

It's strong enough, actually survived a shower on my wrist (I didn't scrub) and the scent was still strong on a paper strip the next day. EDIT: Still strong day four.

Don't know what to think, I love AdP in general but hate the name of this. I personally prefer the original CLUB to this. That was a gentlemen's country club, this seems more youthful, like a night club for young adults?

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Bring back the original Acqua Di Parma Colonia club released in 2015! Why releasing this mainstream generic scent? This new release is just worthless! 👎
ADP Colonia club 2015 was a masterpiece🏆
This new version is very close to Dunhill icon racing green🤔

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I had to wash this one off. I wear the OG and was hoping for that DNA… and although it may be lurking in there somewhere I’m unwilling to wade through all the synthetic effects of the new strain to find it. Hopefully ADP will bring back the good green.
Out of respect for the house, I will give it another shot at some point… just without the expectations of its outstanding predecessor.
Edit: Weeks later tried it again…and was even more repulsed and offended the second time. Whatever woke dipstick put this disaster together needs to be sent packing. Simply the absolute worst release from ADP ever. By a long shot.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: The opening smelled very familiar but I couldn't place my finger on it until @wst mentioned it below. This smells like an acquatic, more delicate version of Versace Eros. The dry down smells very similar to Bleu de Chanel. It smells fine, but unremarkable, and seems to have poor performance. I stand by my earlier complaint regarding the name. "Community Love Unique Bond"...? Really? What does that even mean?

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
ADP what have you done?
I'll say this, if this was just another flanker, i wouldn't mind it. But replacing the original with this is a crime.
Seems to me that someone at ADP thought they needed to appeal to the younger audience so they reformulated it into a generic freshie that everyone could like. It's nothing special.
Always thought Club, Essenza and Intensa was the identity of modern era ADP. Those scents are what people associated with ADP and made them stand their own ground in the fragrance community.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Bought this one in the boutique in Roma, after wearing a tester all day. Worked perfectly in the warmer weather, and was always pleasantly surprised, with the aromatic notes bringing me away from the busy inner city of Roma, very relaxing.
This fragrance will come off a bit harsh for some moments after being applied, but once it's settled, it's very pleasant. When the base notes of musk and cedar kick in, you feel a depth to it, which is unique in its own way. Perfect for warmer weather, the aromatic notes are easy on the nose once settled, and it becomes very elegant and easy to pull off.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I really love the original in the dark green bottle, I was in Helsinki, Finland and passed this new Colonia C.LU.B version in store. I wanted to try this with an open unbiased mind, first I gave it to my female friend to try and her reactions was ''eh its ok'' with abit of a disapproving face. I then tried it and its completely ''run of the mill'' , so basic and nothing special about it at all. Im thinking that the person at Acqua di Parma who decided to replace the original with this must have been suffering from so kind of head injury because its a tragic decision. This new version will be found in TK Maxx at 70% discount soon and even then I wouldn't buy it .

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Men's cologne. Little bit 'grandad', insofar as it reminds me of my actual grandad. I don't know what Britney's Fantasy is doing in the remind's me of line-up, presume it's a troll. This is unremarkable stuff but it is what it is. Blokey smell, nothing more nothing less. As for the name, which seems to be exercising many of you, what would be better? Association? Union? Society? Company? League? Hahahaha I'm so hoping I'm going to find there is something called The League of Gentlemen now.
The dry down is a bit rough tbh, cheap ambery wood. Is not like any cedar I've ever smelled.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: A bit underwhelming from the AdP house. I think they wanted to create a softer version of Colonia Club by using Shiso, but somehow its delicate mint accent is missing. The scent however is relatively linear after about 20-30 minutes. The base seems to contain ISO-E Super (cedar character) and subtle hints of grapefruit, although the latter is not in the scent profile listing. This is all softened by a musky quality most likely due to the ISO-E Super as well. What it can be equated to is a watered-down version of Bleu de Chanel, without the other subtleties of it soft mint and slight floral appeal.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: I've a few Acqua di Parma's, including the green bottle Colonia Club. Whether a good or bad fragrance, this (re-) naming is just stupid. C'mon AdP, you can do better.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells lika Armani - Code with alot of Ambroxan in it.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Do not confuse Colonia C.L.U.B. with the previous Colonia Club (which I did not like anyway). No mint in this one.
And even not a lot of citrus or bergamot. It rather has a nice elegant clean soapy vibe that turns into a skin scent quite soon. If you are looking for a heavy performing long lasting scent you better abstain. But if you don't mind spraying a bit more often, this is a nice freshy.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content:
"'C.L.U.B.' seriously? Who cleared this as the name?"

Agree. That's way off-brand, which in turn affects customer perception, expectation, and trust — which will all have an effect on how the fragrance smells to those who use it.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: Tested Colonia C.L.U.B. today and unfortunately it’s quite boring and takes a step back from the original Colonia Club. The previous version was a beautiful minty fougere which really stood out from the ADP range. I’ve spoken to their head-office and apparently the original Colonia Club is temporarily out of stock but I think this new formulation has replaced the old one.

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: …agree…could the name be any more confusing ? no, no it could not…reflects a popular style of showing all the rivets, big rivets ie front of new Bronco…inexplicable and not elegant imo…the scent sounds great…i am a fan only of Colonia and Pura and find others too fussy…this sounds good to me, can’t wait to try…

product_name: Colonia C.L.U.B. Acqua di Parma
review_content: "C.L.U.B." seriously? Who cleared this as the name? Why take away from the original Colonia Club with such a gimmicky title? How do I differentiate this from the original when someone asks me what I'm wearing? I really question AdP's marketing team sometimes. I look forward to trying the fragrance though.

product_name: Peonia Nobile Edizione Speciale Acqua di Parma
review_content: nothing like peony nobile. the most heady amber floral with the sweetest honey sparks.

product_name: Peonia Nobile Edizione Speciale Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Eh, if they had been given to me in a "blind test" I would never in my life have come up with the fact that I was smelling something that, probably on a wishful thinking basis, was called peony. Although (to do perfumers justice) it should be mentioned that capturing it in perfumes is not an easy matter, so not too often it succeeds....

In the uncommonly beautiful flacon of the special edition Peonia Nobile, I therefore discovered something that surprised me to no end. Unfortunately - and as expected. A sweet-plastic interpretation of a flower or some-flowers, on a base of amber resin, known from too many compositions and pouring hectoliters from everywhere. Not high-flying. Naturally - it couldn't do without a little fruity accent and a small dose of overly sedate patchouli, too. It's a pity - a special edition and "nobile" in the name should oblige something (besides the price), though.

Performance parameters: 3 fathomable "puffs" after 2h leave only the "tip" of ambergris close on the skin. The ambergris is a write-off of Christian Lacroix for Avon, the ladies' version. Nota bene: if one would like to get this Edizione Speciale by the "layering" method, I guess that some inexpensive, sweet and floral perfume mixed with the aforementioned Avon Lacroix should "do the trick".

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Clearly marketed as Acqua Di Parma's prestige line of perfumes, the Note Di Colonia range are beautiful bottles, beautifully packaged, and contain pleasant and well rounded fragrances. This is the perfect white shirt and suit perfume, to be worn when you wish to feel expensive and confident. However, as with all Acqua Di Parma, its fragrance is light, and does not stick out the day. For the price these regularly retail for, they are not worth it, but if you can get one on sale, then it is a lovely perfume to add to your collection. Note 3 I believe is based on "The Triumphant Return" from the opera Aida, and the fragrance does evoke a victorious and successful image when sprayed. A Soft floral and powdery base, with a strong citrus punch when first sprayed, this is a more refined, breezier and sophsticated cousin of its ADP brothers and sisters.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is interesting, particularly with the jasmine/ginger combination with the olibanum/myrhh balsamic accord. Jasmine is a powerful influence and it manifests prominently, especially in the opening. Some people describe it as "abrasive". Its distinctive. Its somewhat powdery, and should probably have a "Powdery" accord listed in the stack. Acqua di Parma Note di Colonia III is good, but not 4.45 rating good for me. I prefer Acqua di Parma's more classic Citrus Aromatic fragrances.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Is this extra special or something that breaks ground? No. However, the blending and quality of this particular fragrances's make up is simply stunning. A gorgeous creation that gives you everything in the range from Acqua Di Parma in a 5oz. flacon like bottle. Take Ginepro from the Mediterranean line, Sandalo Concentree from the Colonia line (sadly discontinued) & Mirrah as well. Then have Colonia Intensa at the very top to give it that clean and soapy freshness and you have this masterpiece of a fragrance. Theres a, richness and depth as the top notes of citrus fade with this woody, vetiver, floral & spice that slowly builds leading into a sophisticated yet simple drydown of subtle sweetness from the Tonka Bean, myrrh and a very leather like clean scent. It's almost Barbershop like sophistication that meets church like stoicism and you have a majestic rendition of 2 separate genres collectively melding as one. This is not for the young'ins of today. This is class, maturity and subtle sophistication.

Just a brilliant creation that in terms of quality takes a back seat to no one.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
My favorite in the line. Dry down is clean, resinous, powdery and slightly soapy. Reminds me of a Prada, maybe Iris d'Cedre, but not as cloying or overly powdery. Definitely worth a sample.

After a few wearings, to me it sort of sits in between Prada Amber Pour Homme and Amber Pour Homme Intense making it quite versitile. Going to have to pick up a discounted bottle.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Haven’t worn this in years and sprayed some on this afternoon. It starts out a bit ordinary and a bit abrasive but drys down smoother and more interesting. Although I liked the opening, I wasn’t sure it was for me until it dried down. When it settled down I really began to enjoy it a lot. The final drydown has the signature ADP soapy, powdery barbershop DNA that I love. This is one of my favorite Acqua di Parma Colonia's. Performance is fairly decent but could be a little better on skin. It smells Italian almost like a Prada l’Homme. I’d sum it up by describing it as a fresh, powdery, sweet coca-cola. It smells very similar to Mancera Tonka Cola with a bit more woodiness. I detect a touch of cedar.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Just finished the large decant I bought years ago....what a great fragrance. An absolute pleasure. An insane bargain at some of the prices I've seen this go for.,

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Found a bottle for 148 dollars. For that price I think this is good. Basically a fresher take on amber and resins with a faint soapy dry down. A nice wear when you don’t want to beat people over the head with your fragrance. Summer nights / fall would be best times to wear imo although winter would be fine as well. This smells attractive without giving off cologne bro vibes which I hate.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Anyone know who the perfumer(s) is/are on this one? Seems to be conspicuously absent from everything I have read.

Edit: for those interested, confirmed with AdP… Nicolas Bonneville with the creative direction of Francois Demachy.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Last time I smelt this sort of frankincense and vetiver was William Penhaligon, though I'm sure there's closer comparisons. In any case, it opens up with that cologne like manly alcohol blast, and settles into the amber warm but slightly green frankincense vetiver combo. Very smooth, wearable, cologne vibes - surely there's something 1/3rd the price though that does the same thing? Feels natural, even if the reality is it's synthetics, the vibe is quality. Perfect end of summer, should work all year, not quite fresh frag.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: As usual Acqua di Parma does not miss a beat. Bright and fresh citrusy opening notes, spicy jolts of ginger transport the senses in an exciting oriental kaleidoscope, rich in olebane clearly perceptible to dry, to dry-down a fabulous triumph of labdanum and Tonka bean wrapped in a smoky and enveloping myrrh. A fabulous warm and sensual fragrance, which evokes the magic of the East. Amber sillage with spicy aftermath. Good durability.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Not a fan of this house in general but I don't mind this. More Spring/Summer to me. It's definitely similar to a lot of other fragrances and being a cologne, the price is asking a lot.

Edit: After wearing it for the day I can confirm this dries down to a generic scent and is not for me.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Searching for a sample of this in the UK.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The best out of the 5 'Notes', I agree with the reviewer below me. Well blended, transparent amber-tonka cologne. The notes that shines here is labdanum. I happen to love that note. I’d say this is a super upscale designer that is modern, chic and likeable. This is for people that don’t do ‘beast mode’. Honestly I am not crazy about beast mode performance on men anyway.

While it is really good, I do think this is overpriced. It is not worth over 150 euro for 150 ml. Quality should, and can be had at a lower price point.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: I just blind bought this, at first I thought blah its just ok but I keep trying and trying to love it and you know what? Its working!! I'm really starting to understand how beautiful it really is.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Note III opens with a mild orange, imbued with incense resins that make the aroma very bold and heady. Myrrh is certainly the key player. I don't like this application of myrrh, I've seen it in a number of other fragrances, and I find it to have the same the same effect for them all. It gives the fragrance a very crude feeling.

The oversoul of Note III is very much like Note II. They feel kindred to one another. Note III is a bit more tame and tapered by raw comparison, but still gives me a very similar impression as Note II.

It's like you walk into the bathroom after your girlfriend is done; and she forgets to flush the toilet; and you slip and fall, and your arm dunks inside the toilet (but she's such a sweetheart—it's not as bad as it could be).

I hate to say that this fragrance could be therapeutic, but I guess it could have that effect, if at least something. I don't find that it's very high energy. It's kind of gloomy—like Note II. That being said, it doesn't do much for being active.

I don't get much more out of the notes either. Pretty much just a dominant mild orange with lots of hazy resins underneath.

It kind of lacks the sweetness to be attractive, so I can't say I see any potential in formal wear. And I don't think you would turn many heads or impress anyone with this either. It's a bit too underwhelming and simple for that unfortunately.

Performance was incredibly average. A little stronger than Note II. But sadly—to no avail. The orange is much more dominant than anyone has testified. It remains strong throughout the duration of the fragrance. Yet once again—not really to much avail.

An atrocity to the Note di Colonia line to say the least.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: I loved my grandmother dearly and still miss her nearly 40 years after she left this world. This is a scent she would have liked back as she was getting up in her years back in the 1970's. It would have probably been best used to cover up the smell of cigarettes. While I feel a great sentimentality for the smells of that time this association isn't at all positive. It's just not at all the kind of scent I like now.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Sampled it on paper: the 4 frags of this "Note di Colonia" collection are great, and n.III is the most interesting imo. Beautiful airy AdP's citrusy opening, resinous floral heart, and heavenly resin/myrrh/tonka drydown.
Basically a similar opening to Colonia Intensa, and a drydown going towards Colonia Mirra.

I should retest it on skin... but at the current retail price I would recommend other fragrances. But when it'll arrive at discounters, I'll rethink it!

Edit: I now own it. Crystal-clear masculine leaning fresh opening (citrus/ginger and probably some watery/calone notes also) with a hint of florals, and the drydown is all about a sexy vanillic myrrh bringing it back in the unisex zone (similar to AdP Colonia Mirra and Armani Myrrhe Imperiale) supported by tonka. Heavy projection in the first hour that will become moderate after that, and settles down at the 4-hours mark. Great longevity.
Simple, crowdpleasing, but very well blended. At the high-end of the designer world, but still not at a niche level imo. Glad I own it, but also glad that I paid just a fraction of the full retail price.
Recommended? Yes, but don't spend more than $150 for a 5oz bottle!

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very interesting and unexpected smell. It has a fresh (even cologne like) vibe to it despite the seemingly heavy and opaque notes (probably because it's AdP after all lol). That freshness comes from the combination of mandarin, ginger and jasmine. And myrrh here is fizzling and coke like, reminds me of serge lutens myrrh.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I don't understand the moderate sillage votes because this is a BEAST,and the sprayer is the lightest of the AdP fragrances!

A 10/10,it truly is,so beautiful. It gives off the same fruity-smokey-woody vibe as Creed Aventus, not a clone in anyway,and I don't mean to compare, I hate comparing scents but the vibe is similar.

This is among the most beastly fragrances in the beast mode section of my collection!

The compliment factor is very high as well.
I love it,it's a masterpiece and I love AdP.

Shelleyan below said it well '10 out of 10 points'

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content:
FIRST SNIFF: I was introduced to this part of the line by the ADP SA who was tending the perfume bar downstairs at the Houston Neiman's store. She laid out the three scents in this grouping and had me smell each in order. I was informed prior to smelling them that each one is stronger and more full bodied than the last. So the first in the series would be the lightest and most understated. The last the most robust and full-bodied. (a true assessment)

Like the others in the group, it immediately obvious that this is a well crafted, well-made scent. This is the crown jewel of the trio! Certainly the most "niche" of the three, it has a strong EDP body that is not only long lasting, but also well projecting. Hard to believe that scent this robust comes from a transparent liquid IMO!

THE PICTURE IT PAINTS: Dark room. Hot date. You applied a spartan 2 sprays of this 90 minutes earlier and it is smelling just as good as when you put it on. If this scent were a fabric, it would be thick, heavy layers of silk and velvet. In Dark colors, Maroon, brown, black and gold stitching and embellishments throughout. A scent so warm, and rich, dense and enveloping you want to curl up in it and just sleep forever.

IN THE BRAND FAMILY: Because the bottle is Lalique and it is so limited it may be worthy of a collector's cabinet. Of the three in this collection this leans the most niche but it's not weird enough or strange enough to be a strong niche contender IMO. This gives the dark brown bottles of ADP a run for their money to be sure.

Full Bottle worthy? - maybe
Sample worthy? - YESSSSSSSSSSSSS

PARTING THOUGHTS: There is a definite cedar wood presence here that (unlike most cedar notes) is remarkable and well done. It seems like it is sitting 8 feet from me, an amazing effect to be sure. A mysterious and confusing effect seems to be caused by this scent - each time I sniff it i smell something different. Like a strange painting in a horror movie that changes to something different each time I turn away from it and I look back and see it has changed but I didn't see anyone or anything happen to cause it. I have that kind of feeling with this. Like each sniff is giving me a different take on the while scent profile.

This scent is a winner, the only one you need to know or pay attention to should your path ever cross the Note di Colonia collection.

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is a weird (but not bad) neo-Oriental.. I thought it came off a little boozy; myrhh is definitely not the strongest note...

product_name: Note di Colonia III Acqua di Parma
review_content: mmmm love it

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: The opening melange of citruses in Cedro di Taormina is beautiful. Its a creamy melange, probably a manifestation of the lavender and labdanum. The aromatics and woods give texture to the association with the flora of Taormina. And for a Woody Citrus Aromatic, this scent profile is a bit darker. This is up there with Mirto di Panarea.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Whyyy!!! Do they keep discontinuing fragrance I fall in love with.
This is such a heavenly mood lifting freshie for the warmer months and I only have half a bottle left.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Absolutely gorgeous ! Lemon an cedar but done in a perfectly elegant manner ! Casual Italian gentleman’s fragrance.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Cedro di Taormina was the second favourite of all the Aqua di Parma scents I decided to give a try.

It’s a fresh, green, citrusy, aromatic, woody scent in line with all Aqua di Parma Blu Mediterraneo’s line. This stood out the most as being the most powerful in this blue line but I decided to get Mirto di Panarea because it leaned more feminine…and because of that gorgeous limited edition packaging.

Cedro di Taormina was more masculine and stronger. It has lavender, black pepper, cedar and vetiver. I would still say it’s more a unisex fragrance, if judged on its own merit, I would definitely wear it!

Lasts for about 4 hours with moderate sillage on clothing. Maybe I would revisit this next summers when I run out of Mirto di Panarea!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This range is pretty much safe to blind buy.
Unisex aquatic timber, cool and fresh, with some citrus leaf and peper.
Light, fresh, easy to wear.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This fits the brand copy about lush greenery blended in with the volcanic rocks perfectly. It opens with juicy citrus fruits of orange, lemon and lime. The greens arrive with basil that gives it an herbal, shrubbery feeling and the pepper and lavender somehow serves to make me think of rocky terrain.

I've never been to Sicily, but I've seen the Godfather 2 enough times to have a feeling of the landscape in my head. That green shrubbery pepper feeling mixes in with the vetiver and labdanum to perfectly keep this scenery throughout the experience. Cedar here young, green tree branch variety. Very natural.

This is a transportive fragrance and it's a shame that Acqu Di Parma has discontinued this and Ginepro di Sardegna. Worth checking out if you like aromatic vetiver with some touches of wood and lavender. Pepper is fairly prominent so if you don't like pepper then get a sample because it has a small learning curve.

Scent 9.3/10
Performance 5/10

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Finished my tiny sample. A nice fresh, early summer perfume. Agree there is some liquorice/minty thing going on here. It's really nice, really relaxing. Very unisex. 7/10

Edit omg I keep smelling this on my wrist and I love it more and more. Need another decant!!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is minty, peppery wood scent. Like a previous user mentioned, the opening can resemble a licorice type accord. I detect zero citruses in this one. Light, refreshing with moderate performance.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Cedro de Taormina, my everyday juice for warmer months.

•3-12 sprays.
(skin+shirt)
•3-6 hrs. longevity.
•Projection is modest.

Citrusy, lightly woody, and musky----It is perfect for Texas heat and wears well in my cigar shop or wherever.

Cedro de Taormina is a must have for me---simply the best summer scent. 💯

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: I really enjoy this one and have half a bottle left - cannot find another anywhere due to it discontinuation. If anyone in the UK has a bottle to sell, I'm your guy!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Cedro di Taormina is okay. You get an opening of citrus, lavender, cedar and petitgrain. Around 20 minutes in you get basil, vetiver and black pepper also joining the party. When it's stabilised you get a balance of lavender, herby green and wood in the general profile but you can still smell all the notes. It's skilfully blended. Unfortunately for me, the combination of petitgrain and labdanum gives me a slight headache when I smell it on my arms. It's only when the petitgrain goes and the labdanum fades that I can enjoy Cedro di Taormina.

An hour and a quarter in it's fading rapidly and feeling more like an eau de cologne than an eau de toilette. At this stage, it feels to me like it was a perfume made by a committee, half of whom wanted to make Bvlgari's Pour Homme Soir, nearly half of whom wanted to make Guerlain's Homme L'Eau Boisee and one person wanted to make Tom Ford's Italian Cypress. And as you expect from decision making by committee, it hasn't quite hit the mark in any of these directions. To call it boring is being rather harsh. To call it cheap smelling is simply wrong. It's just somehow not quite hit the mark in a way that's very difficult to put your finger on.

Some three and a half hours later the perfume is powering away quite nicely after I'd gone for a walk. But 20 minutes after getting home it's fading again. So while I can understand people complaining that Cedro di Taormina fades quickly, it clearly does stick around as a skin scent. In total, I get about eight and a half hours from it. However, clearly this one is at its best in warmer conditions. I just think that this perfume is a case of defeat snatched from the jaws of victory.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: This was a total dud for me. Not surprised it’s been discontinued because it’s just not very interesting at all. Even after a heavy spraying it’s barely detectable in 45 minutes. Dry down is flat, boring and cheap smelling. Good riddance.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Citrus and pencil shavings, finally decided not for me. Bottle been around for a bit, time to sell.
2.5/5

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells Awesome, this is the 2nd best in the collection behind Ginepro which is a classic. All masculine. Crisp. Its a woody, zesty, peppery and Lavenderish scent. I get compliments with this one. I bought a bottle for my collection. Its long lasting. I recommend a try or buy for a man

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Woody and slightly citrusy opening. Cedary opening but dries down to a vetiver base. Not as fresh as the other ADP Blue line. Nice but not in love with it. Scent: 6, Longevity: 7.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: I got a sample of this and it was always going to be a wild card but unfortunately this isn't the scent for me. I definitely smell the lavender and the cedar, the labdanum too. It pulls very masculine on me and becomes quite sharp and cloying as it dries down. I can't report on longevity as I didn't leave it on all day, unfortunately. I'm giving it to my father as it seems quite appropriate for an older man.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: a great fragrance, so fresh so citrus and italian summer.. a big shame it is no longer in production!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: It's citrus, and woody, and a bit herbaceous. It pulls toward the more "masculine" end of unisex, if you associate cedar/vetiver with masculine. The cedar is pretty strong in it, and the lavender exists in giving it a touch of camphor. I think the woods/camphor/citrus are what some of the reviews below are associating with cleaning products. If the lavender was less camphor- or just not present, I feel this would be a "home run" for most. I do like it. I just wish that one note was dialed back.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I was excited to try this as it is my first offering from AdP and most say it's the best from the line!

Not a fan of this one. Boring cedar dominant fragrance that I kept waiting for to grab my attention and change, but no, very linear. I can see this working better in the heat, it's autumn here now, but I am not a big fan of the scent. Citrus and cedar are in the top and stay that way the entire time, bleh.

This reminds me of my great-grandmother, not that it smells like an old lady (I hate that saying), but it reminds me of her.

Sad miss on this one, don't think I will be trying any others from the house as none grab my attention.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Woke up to an early Fall day in the mid 70s, so decided to test a summer freshie. Citrus notes jump out first, then a masculine blend of additional notes: lavender, pettigrain, cedar and vetiver are the most dominant. I like Cedro di Taormina but feel it’s not for me—but not a downvote. Agree with a reviewer below, this will smell better on male skin.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I blind-bought this, because I often like natural-smelling, Italian-style scents, I'd been interested in trying something from Acqua di Parma for some time and the 30ml version of this was available in a probably Covid-inspired discount-on-discount-on-discount deal on Groupon. I liked the idea of having this as a travel-friendly summer option (in case I ever got around to going anywhere ever again). As yesterday was a hot summer day where I live, I decided to try the fragrance.

I've had a couple of scents that have instantaneously struck a chord with me and just seemed "right" (Bvlgari Soir, one of the Issey summer flankers, probably Davidoff Leather Blend) and maybe a few others that, whether or not they've immediately felt right to me, have really impressed me right away. Cedro di Taormina probably does just seem right to me and anyhow its quality was delightfully, almost overwhelmingly evident to me even at first spray. It does indeed smell natural to me and probably is evocative of Mediterranean landscape. It also has something of an old-school, semi-barbershop feel, without feeling at all dated. I find the combination very appealing. I can understand that the old-school aspect might cause many people to think it an unexceptional fragrance but, while I wish I could compare it to other AdP scents, I'm inclined to say that actually this is exceptional, in the sense that to my mind it is an exceptionally plausible, well-blended, restrained but sophisticated, classical kind of fragrance.

Most if not all of the notes listed are there on my skin at varying stages but the stars of the show are the citrus, silky lavender, some cedar of course and, in particular, the leathery, slightly animalic, semi-powdery labdanum. The labdanum alone definitely renders this masculine on my skin. For me it also tilts this slightly away from spring-summer to, say, later spring, summer and some of the autumn.

Sillage is moderate and certainly adequate for me (it's the kind of fragrance that reminds you every now and then that it's still right there). Longevity, surprisingly, is good, if not excellent. I directly sprayed this onto either forearm twice for test purposes and can still smell it without trying after 18 hours.

Love it. Love everything about it.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is pretty nice but very different than I was expecting. I don't smell very much cedar, just mainly getting a cool herbal blast that smells very minty to me. I'm reminded of scents like Guerlain Homme and Cartier Roadster.

Performance is good. I haven't tried many from the blue Mediterraneo line yet but I like Fico di Amalfi more.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I am usually jealous of how good men's colognes smell because I am so much more inclined toward fresh, sporty, clean smells than the (stereotypically) sweet, fruity, powdery "feminine" scents. Of course, not all feminine fragrances fall into those categories - but when I see a (usually) blue or green "men's" version of a fragrance next to a (often) pink or purple "women's" version, I almost always end up preferring the more masculine version. So much so that I have happily worn many masculine fragrances over the last 15 years or so, even when a feminine version exists (i.e. Liz Claiborne Curve for Men, Antonio Banderas Blue Seduction for Men, Davidoff Cool Water for Men, etc.). And so, thus, started my overly-simplistic view of men's vs. women's fragrance profiles.

As my fragrance journey and education has advanced, particularly recently after discovering Fragrantica(!), I have been enlightened by the discovery of just how vast the variety of fragrances are, including the wide assortment of unisex fragrances, particularly all of the high-end and high-quality stuff, as well as both masculine and feminine fragrances that fall under different fragrance classifications, or groups. Namely, that what I actually preferred were not strictly men's vs. women's scents (and in being politically correct, nothing is truly "male" or "female", so instead I'd like to clarify that I mean "masculine" and "feminine" as per generic societal constructs... but even those fall on a spectrum within which anyone can happily place themselves wherever they see fit, but I digress), but, more specifically, aquatics and fresh, aromatic, green, clean, woody.

So I recently ordered over 20 different fragrance samples across these categories, including unisex, masculine and feminine fragrances, to broaden my horizons and to educate myself. Enter one of the prototypical (read: hugely popular and revered) brands of unisex fragrances, Acqua di Parma, which I thought would be a safe place to start given its status and its wide assortment of unisex offerings.

AdP Cedro di Taormina was up first. The description makes it seem to be all of the things I love: aromatic, fresh, clean, green. I had to try it! My thoughts? Amazing... absolutely amazing..... for a guy. How is this unisex?? This coming from a person who has worn men's cologne! Like actual cologne presumably MEANT for men! I mean, this scent reminds me of the guy who is effortlessly confident, cool-headed, easy-going, friendly, charming, and always smiling or putting one on your face. He's sexy in a relaxed, guy-next-door kinda way. All good things. But, I want to date him, not BE him: I really do not see any kind of woman that would actually wear this. Nothing in anything I am smelling here reminds me of any woman, of any age or creed, that would wear this. Seriously not one to judge any confident girl who wants to rock masculine scents (*raises hand*), but I don't think it will be this one, for me. That said, the next guy I date will definitely be getting this as a gift for Valentine's Day. ;)

For me: 4/10 (delicious, but bit too masculine)
For a guy: 9/10 (yes, please!)

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The fragrance opens very zestily and spicy, the opening notes combine well creating a good and strong initial impression. The opening lasts for only a few moments, almost immediately the mid notes will come up; the black pepper and lavender add to the spicy and floral notes; the initial citrus opening subsides a bit as the mid and base notes become more prominent. From the base, the cedar is the most prominent note, whereas the labdanum and vetiver add just whiff. The projection drops very quickly from the opening to dry-down; also, the zesty and sharp citrus notes of the opening fade out and leave their space to the woody and citrus notes of the cedar. Once fully dried-down, the fragrance can be summarized as a low projecting cedar fragrance with light spicy and floral notes. The fragrance feels relatively fresh, modern, pleasant but not special.

Category: Woody aromatic.
Batch reviewed: 2020
Wow Rating: 3/10. A soft, cedar fragrance, pleasant but unimpressive.
Dislike Rating: 0/10. This fragrance contains no offensive notes.
Uniqueness: 6/10. A mostly cedar-based fragrance, it is a relatively unique scent.
Mass Appeal: 7/10. This is a soft cedar fragrance, enhanced by floral and spicy notes that will please most people.
Projection: 1/10. Dry-down projection is very low.
Sillage: 0/10. Almost none.
Application: Six or more atomizations to compensate for poor performance.
Longevity: 3/10. No more than three hours.
Seasons: Spring.
Occasions: Formal events, outdoor gatherings, office/business casual. This is an office-friendly fragrance.
Versatility: 6/10. Moderate would be higher if performance would be at least moderate.
Gender: Unisex.
Ages: Any
Recommendation: A pleasant fragrance with very poor performance. Do not buy it.
Blind-Buy: Yes, but only if you are familiar with cedar as a note in fragrances.
Summary: A soft projecting cedar fragrance with some light spicy and floral notes, good but not great in any way.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
another one i desperately wanted to love but not even the presence of cedar or citruses brought me round. next to others in the Blu line this feels rather heavy which initially was a deviation from the Blu line's aesthetic i welcomed. as sad as i am to see this is being discontinued (because i am confident that this morphs beautifully on the right body chemistry) i can see why it has landed in the chop pile.

CdT would have fared better as a variant on the Colonia line; you expect a stronger level of intensity and denseness from offerings outside of the Blu range. here's where things got interesting: the Colonia Sandalo flanker, which at its base smells almost identical to Cedro Taormina, offers much the same wooded experience but in a cohesive way. that is where Cedro Taormina falls apart on my skin - loads of strong notes shouting and competing with each other. there's also something that runs throughout that reminds me of vegetable soup. i swear to god i can smell V8 tomato juice and long simmered celery through the entire wear time.

in fairness i think it is wonderful ADP wishes to incorporate more wood dominant fragrances to their catalogue and the longevity of Cedro Taormina is impressive. the one area i feel this worked for the Blu line is that it compliments in all weather - hot, cold, humid, dry.

this was ahead of its time and feels like a very polished rough draft, which i hope to mean is a sign of more woody offerings to come from ADP.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Bemused by the note pyramid...is it possible that Cedro is the Italian word for Cedrat (citron) as well as for cedar? The picture of an actual cedrat on the marketing photos makes me think this was conceived as a cedrat based offering. I don’t get much by way of pencil shavings, though the warm citrus is front and centre. V pleasant, if a bit corporate.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Lo trovo buono ma non eccezionale gli darei un 7 cmque lo trovo simile a terre hermes!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Gentlemen: On those days where just a hint of classy, refined essence is your aesthetic aim, this is your scent. Warm days when you might be in close proximity to others and you want to exude trace amounts of taste and refinement? This is your scent. When you want to leave an impression that you are well-groomed, conscientious of your personal toilette, yet never want to bear the humiliation of being labeled “cologne guy”? Wear this. Are you a habitual oversprayer? Have at it- satiate your desires. Apply Cedro liberally without fear of douchebaggery. Behaves like a EDC, so elegant and uplifting. Simple citrus, pepper, lavender and cedar. Lovely gentleman’s scent for summer.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Sunlight in a bottle. I have a fantasy about being a well-groomed Italian gentleman in a crisp beige linen suit and jute espadrilles, luncheoning on freshly caught grilled octopus and caprese salad with a sparkling glass of white wine and beautiful madonna at my side on the patio of a seaside restaurant somewhere along the Amalfi Coast. This (or Essenza, Chinotto di Liguria, or Ginepro di Sardinia) would be my fragrance - sparkling, fresh, zesty, charismatic, sexy, and mama mia oh so Italian. BIG love.

8/10

Edit: Finally got a full bottle of this. It's been quite a while since I plowed through my sample, but this still smells as good as I remember. A bright and quite herbal opening gives way to a smooth, sultry, creamy woodsy drydown. Just lovely. Performance has been quite good, with around 7-8 hours of longevity and 2 hours of projection. Can't wait to try this in the summer heat.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: The best of the Blu Mediterraneo line. It's a very simple fragrance: comprised of juicy orange and lemon, and smooth cedar. It has great performance (for AdP, at the very least). I took a decant of this with me on a trip to Puerto Rico; as I walked along El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, the breeze from the ocean would swirl this fragrance in the air around me. Now, every time I smell this fragrance, I'm taken back to the enchanted island. Will definitely be buying a full bottle.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Generic, pleasant, powdery soap. Lavender itself is a soapy note, but there’s something about the combination of citrus and cedar with the lavender that turn it to pure soap. If you like soap, this is it.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Yuck. Smells like traditional herbal Chinese medicine.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
AdP’s Cedro di Taormina is very much a masculine fragrance - more so than most of the Blu Mediterraneo range.

It opens up very bright and green and citrusy for the first hour or so - and is quite pleasant - before cedar, vetiver and black pepper dominate the fragrance of what it at its heart a rather dull and generic perfume. Just like many of Acqua di Parma's Blu range this falls under 'a miss.'

Longevity is maybe 4 hours or so as a skin scent without much projection.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Cedar without the typical spiciness as found in other fragrances...and that paired with a nice lemon/citron scent.

This is nice because, as mentioned by others, it doesn't swim in Iso-E Super. Nor is it spicy.

It has more longevity than I would have expected given its lighter and non smothering scent.

It makes me think of a warm dry hilly area being surrounded by old cedar trees and looking down upon lemon orchards.

Very nice!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: What looks like the good thing of this scent I get only when I press my nose on my skin to smell it. Apart from that, I can't help but remember of the insipid Hèrmes Eau de Gentiane Blanche. A bit of joy would be welcoming.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: A like but not a love. It has that ADP vibe to it, but I'm not as fond of cedar as others might be.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Cedro di Taormina is a masculine aromatic. The fragrance opens with a stingy, bold woodsy essence. It's a touch sour, and has a distinct masculine notion to it in that sourness. The woodsy essence is enveloped by an aqueous body—consisting of citruses, basil, and vetiver. They give the woodsy essence a strong transparency effect. And in their crude, although tinctured forms, add to the sourness a bit. If you get close, you can sense a faint bit of sweetness from the lavender.

It definitely has a Married With Children vibe to it, something along the tune of "Love and Marriage". I don't really find that the two accords compliment each other too well. The aqueous body doesn't have the sweetness or stimulation it needs. The vividness of the notes are very mellow-dramatic and drowned. It doesn't freshen the woods, as much as it does seemingly does pollute it further. It could have used some magnolia and some cherry blossom, just like Taormina itself.

The fragrance is very unique though. It's so bold and masculine—it really comes off with a strong "tough guy" vibe. And I think you really have to be a tough guy to wear this. Although I've noticed that the fragrance seems to project much better in very high heat—and is almost very enjoyable even. Uplifting and inspiring. Go easy on the sprays though. It's certainly one of the strongest fragrances in the Mediterraneo series.

If it matches your persona, then you really might find something neat here Cedro di Taormina. I wouldn't call it a crowd pleaser though, so it's not likely to get any raves amongst the crowd. Although it might be able to provide its beholder with some sense of comfort and security among them.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Bleu de Chanel in a circular bottle. I was about to say 'with niche price tag' but hey, I believe this is cheaper than the Chanel, so I'd guess it wouldn't be a bad choice after all.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Another well done fragrance from the master blenders ADP. This is a very Intoxicating, Fresh, Crispy, and Pungent scent. Leans more masculine. It gets compliments. It will fill the room on initial spray. I get cedar, pepper and lavender mostly. Sillage and projection are solid. 3 hrs of a 3 feet distance smell. 5 to 7 hrs lasting power overall. This and ADP Ginepro are the very best for men.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
A breath of cedar that is quickly overtaken by citrus. The citrus is really good and lifelike although before I could place exactly what fruit I was smelling it shifted again. It flirts with being an aquatic cologne and threatens to smell like blue toilet and has seconds of pure fresh sea-breeze before settling into basil.

So much basil. I don't mean pesto. It has some of the licorice notes of holy basil, but it also smells very green and leafy -- like if classic basil smelled how it looked rather than how it smells when you are cooking with it. Unpicked basil? It is lush and really quite interesting.

In the end I'm not sure how I feel about it. It is right on the line of being too cologne-like for me, but every time I think it's crossed it it's just too interesting. I'll have to revisit when I'm looking for green and beachy not woody.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is Bleu de Chanel's more confident, relaxed and better travelled older brother. Not a dig on BDC but to me this is an improvement and smells less artificial and less sweet. Really good stuff. Buy this for someone who liked a sample of BDC, they'll like this even more and feel special cause its not as mass market.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Just bought a full bottle. Well balanced, zesty and bright citrus that plays perfect with a very clean cedar. Theres some very gentle spices that open it up even further. Well composed and doesn't lean to far on either side. Cedar keeps it strong and woody and citrus keeps it fresh and summery, the petitgrain keeps it soapy and masculine. It has a transportive quality about it that takes you seaside on the Mediterranean with the ocean breezes, kind of like the bottle implies.
A++ Aqua di Parma. A must have for summer.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Sprayed this on while walking through airport and duty free section yesterday - instant mood lifter and you cannot help but travel with your mind when smelling this. I have a soft spot for mediterranean scents and this one (the whole range) is no exception. The initial smell is a bit fresher and more aromatic than the dry down. Top notes are really on point. It gradually gets woodier with the pepper and lavender checking in. Surprisingly good longevity with moderate sillage on me. My colleague, who sat two seats right from me on the plane got soft hints of this. It all ends with a soft powdery finish, maybe the vetiver.
Love it - perfectly unisex and well worth the money.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Oh man.
This is the type of fragrance that puts a smile on my face, no matter what.
Received it yesterday and I am not going to review it yet. It's 8 degrees C.

No, I'm wearing the other fragrance I received yesterday:
Chergui by Serge Lutens. A type of fragrance that will have "to grow on me".
As if that would be even possible. A parfum doesn't grow on us, we (try to) grow on them.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Although I have never been in Taormina, but if it smells so, I have to look there. Fresh scent of orange blossoms in the breeze of the sea is accompanied by Vetiver - green grass. It will hold on your skin from evening until morning, when it smells only lavender and resin from Labdanum from the nearby meadow.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: the most i like in entire aqua frag series. gorgeous cedar. it smells heavenly. i always thought there is some juniper in it. nopee acording to the site.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
As a citrus/woody, it immediately reminded me of Guerlain L'Homme L'Eau Boisée so I thought I'd do a side by side review. The citrus in AdP is a general bitter citrus accord whereas the Guerlain has a single precise spike of lime in the gamut. Again with AdP has general woodsy accord whereas the Guerlain has a more discrete woody note/s. The overall vibe of the AdP is a high quality, natural, fragrance for fragrance sake that invoked images of sunshine and nature whereas the Guerlain is leaning towards a classic aftershave i.e. it could be 5% Aramis and it has something bordering on a soapy/powderiness. The AdP is fuller, denser and more complex whereas the Guerlain is more attention grabbing (most probably from the Iso E Super)

I personally much prefer the AdP and think it's just a higher quality scent although I could see how a layman (male) on the street might go for the Guerlain because it is more of a standard, traditionally masculine scent. It has scored higher on reviews here.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Intoxicating citrus/cedar combination. I reach for this frequently. One of my favourite fresh scents ever.

9/10

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I received a tester of Cedro di Taormina. This fragrance is really stunning. The evolution is truly great. It starts citrus, then floral and bit spicy evolving on woody and fresh base notes. It ends completely different comparing his debut and it's nice and comfortable. It smells masculine and clean. Cedar disappears quickly, from top notes you can still advert basils with vetiver and cedar wood. So, don't expect the classic citrus summer fragrance, it might be used also in other seasons.

9/10

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The initial blast of Lemon gives way to an absolutely beautiful Cedar note. Whilst the scent is very nice Cedro di Taormina suffers from performance issues. Whilst the longevity is decent (5-6hrs), it is at very best a skin scent, and a very weak one at that.

It's such a shame that it is so weak, because it could've been special.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: 2 hour longevity with minimal sillage. Nice scent for a quickie but otherwise no one will be able to detect this...

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very optimistic composition with lime and cedar. Tried in sunny Catania in December, Sicily. Smell of freshly washed clothes, what each Italian "Donna" hangs on the balcony. Smell of Sicily and holidays. Long lasting, clean unisex. For tranquil soul only.

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is my favourite Acqua di Parma, fresh, woody, masculine, simply amazing!

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content: Spray for my long hair. Perfect smell, longlasting, deep & fresh. I like it so much

product_name: Cedro di Taormina Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The opening of Cedro di Taormina on my skin seems to depend on how much I apply: with only one spray, it's more like a sharp, laundry-like white musk lightly infused with citrus; with two sprays, the sparkling citrus finally comes to life.

My favourite part of Cedro di Taormina starts about 20 minutes later: while the citrus mellows, the cedar, basil and vetiver come through.
