The mid is where the lavender comes into play and again such a stunning natural unsweetened version.. the vetiver in the base holds it altogether in what if it lasted longer than a hour or two
this would be perfect. Performance is its big let down but great to grab when coming out of the shower and you want to extend the feeling of being fresh and clean for a further hour or so.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A solar Vetiver cologne. Fresh, mature, elegant.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Extremely mature, Im talking this is how a 75 year old chess hustler probably smells like. And I wanna clarify that I dont mind fragrances that are somewhat mature like colonia essenza or eau sauvage. But this right here is extreeemely mature, if you dont think its mature than you just dont find any fragrance mature as you dont place an age limit on it which is fine but my personal opinion is that even if youre 40 this is too mature for you... I dont get much citrus, if I had to explain the smell it would be the smell of rosemary but like 5 mins before I wrote this I smelled actual rosemary from a garden and the cologne, the cologne is a much much more potent smell so its not as pleasant as actual rosemary. Anyways that was a chaotic review but yeah, DONT BLIND BUY. Arancia di capri remains my favorite from the brand.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I've been fascinated by Acqua di Parma fragrances for a while now, as their offerings seem to align with my preferences for old-school, classic scents. With that in mind, I’ve made a couple of blind purchases and tested several decants this year. My first blind buy was Fico di Amalfi and I was not disappointed, so encouraged by that success I considered Colonia (original), Colonia Intensa, and Colonia Futura. It was not an easy choice, but I eventually settled on Futura.

Unfortunately, my initial experience with Futura wasn’t as positive as I’d hoped, and I found myself struggling to pinpoint exactly what I didn’t like about it. When I encounter a fragrance like this, that I find hard to evaluate, I tend to wear it for a few weeks, hoping to understand it better. My immediate thought with this particular fragrance was that perhaps my sense of smell was a bit off when I first tried it, and in fact I did find it improved over a few days, so I think there was an issue in that respect. In saying that, I’ve now worn Futura several times and I’m still not convinced by it.

Futura opens with a citrus blend of lemon, bergamot and grapefruit, but I find it hard to distinguish any of those notes. I know it’s citrus, but it’s not sharp, zesty or realistic to my nose. Instead, I find it to be a musty sort of citrus smell. It does have a slight twang to it that I assume to be the pink pepper note, but once again it isn’t easy for me to place it. And there is also something there in the opening that reminds me of the smell of mouldy bread. I have experienced this mouldy bread smell in another fragrance that I should have enjoyed based on its notes, so I’m quite prepared to believe that this is something specific to how I interpret certain combinations of notes. Along the same lines, the very first time I tried Futura, I got a burning plastic smell, but I've not had that since. I've read that Futura contains some Ambroxan and that might be the difficulty I have with this, as it is something that I seem to be sensitive to.

Thankfully, where I’m concerned, the initial stage of Futura’s development passes within a few minutes on my skin and I then find it improves considerably. Gone is the indistinct citrus and mustiness and in comes aromatic and herbal accords, which I find slightly reminiscent of a doctor’s waiting room.

As it evolves further, it is mellowed by a warm smokiness. For me, this middle stage lasts around three hours, before a final stage in which I get something akin to a fruity boiled sweet, which ultimately turns to vetiver. In total, I find Futura lasts six hours + on my skin.

Overall, while Colonia Futura certainly evolves over time and improves on my skin, it hasn’t fully won me over and I'm finding it difficult to rate it. At times, I'm really not that keen, but then I do quite like the latter stages of this fragrance.

My Photo: https://www.fragrantica.com/fragram/fp/315147

Tested: 50ml full bottle.
Seasons / Occasions: Spring and autumn. Informal.
Key thoughts: Musty citrus opening, followed by aromatic, herbal smokiness.
Overall rating: 6/10.
Buy full bottle: No.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is a modern Givenchy Monsieur de Givenchy. Spray them side by side. Same notes, same sillage, same longevity. Same amazing fragrance, and now I don't have to hunt for the original!!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is my go-to everyday scent! It's so refreshing and clean, perfect for the warmer months. The citrus notes are bright and zingy, and the lavender adds a nice touch of sweetness. I love that it's made with natural ingredients too.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: The nose behind this dry, and phenomenal, Fougere is François Demachy. The Grapefruit and Pink Pepper accords give this composition a moden touch, but the rest of the notes are tried and true standards: Bergamot, Clary Sage, Lavender, Lemon and Vetiver. It hardly gets more classic than this. It's not unisex. I don't see anyone other than men over 40 wearing It. It has moderate projection and longevity, so you may want to apply and reapply generously.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura opens brightly and you'll get the Green Cirtus Bitter Herbal opening. You will need to like such opening to like Futura. Young adults may not be used to this as this dna and opening is rather old school green herbal barbershopy. Those of us in the know will know if you will likely like it. The reminds me of scent are pretty accurate too. But I don't think it's worth getting it at retail price. Resellers/Discounters price yes. Good for a sunny and warm hot day.

It's projection for this fresh herbal like scent is pretty decent, better than a few flora Edp under the brand. 2-3 sprays on arm and forehand and it projects at least a feet or two, not too bad. It's staying power and longetivity is probably half a day, maybe 5-6 hours easily.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A Fougere Mature Scent from Acqua Di Parma, Its Masculine, Super Green and Herbatious, a little spicy and smoky and suprisingly, the citrus sweet juicyness of the top notes suprisingly lingers for quite a while on my skin. A great fragrance for the summer time that last around 5-6 hours, with around 1 to 2 hours of moderate projection, Please sample this before buying as not everyone will like this, i will give it a 7.5/10

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Funny it's called "futura", to me it smells the most old school out of the colonia line.
It reminds me of my grandpa when i was young going to the synagogue.
Smells ancient to me. not futuristic in any way.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Bitter, herbal, green citrus fragrance.

Maybe it's the citrus selection or the blending method but this opens with a very bitter, astringent citrus note. I love it. No sweetness here. Like complaining of thirst on a hot day only to sprayed with bitter lemon-infused water.

Within half an hour, it takes a greener feel drying down to a faint herbal, woody smell.

I know it's an EDC (so it shouldn't be unexpected) but longevity is an alien word for this fragrance. I had to respray every 3hrs as it was barely noticeable on the skin after that time.

Longevity is my only complaint. If this performed better, it would be a love for me. Great fragrance for a hot summer (or spring) day but you'll need a decant if you're going to be away from home for a long time.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is quickly becoming one of my most worn fragrances. I especially enjoy it on crisp days towards the end of summer. It's so natural smelling, crisp and green. It's so dry it almost feels savoury to me, and I love that. The citrus is more zesty than juicy, and the herbs are fresh and green. Dries down to a sharp vetiver. My only complaint is that I wish it had a bit more staying power.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Found a bottle full bottle of this at my local flea market for just 30 clams. Colonia Futura is my first step into niche fragrances and I absolutely love it!

opens up super citrusy and slightly spicy. As it dries down I get a mix of herbal floral woodiness with some zing still in the background. I find this to be very classy, smells like something my dad would've worn. That being said this probably isn't for the younger crowd. Not sweet at all and I probably would've hated it a year ago but my nose has changed a lot during my fragrance journey. It smells very familiar but I can't pin down exactly what, It kind of just reminds me of older fragrances.

I wouldn't say this stands out so much that you need it in your collection but for the price I got it, it was hard to pass up. I find it to be very versatile and nonoffensive and I love the scent profile so I will likely be wearing this often.

This was a very nice first step into niche scents for me and I would love to try more fragrances from this house.

6/10

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A mouth watering and light citrus opening that slowly transitions to a rich and long lasting vetiver. Perfect for casual wear. Typically a warm weather fave, but the depth of the vetiver makes it enjoyable in cooler weather as well. As sunny as the box it comes in.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is a nice and refreshing summertime scent, but I wouldn't call it unisex, because it contains many features of old-school masculine colognes. The scent description above is correct: it opens with lemon, bergamot and pink pepper, and I bet there's also some neroli in it. After some minutes, lavender emerges as the main note, aided by spices, herbs, and the still omnipresent bergamot. The closing note is a green-lemony vetiver. It doesn't project very strongly, but its fresh and somewhat sharp presence is felt nonetheless. I'm not sure that it is worth the asking price, because there are hundreds of similar scents in all price categories available worldwide; but other than that, the scent is nice, versatile and office-friendly. Due to the aforementioned vintage-cologne association, I would say that it is better suited to mature men, whereas Zoomers might find it too grandpa-like.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Acqua di Parma in vetiver. Full stop.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very professional classy scent. Amazing citrus opening with an earthy vetiver drydown. Great summer scent, especially for formal daytime events. 8/10 scent with about 4-5 hours longevity on my skin. Personally, I prefer colonia intensa and colonia essenza but if you like a more barbershop feel, then futura is right up your alley.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very lemony and woody. I sadly don’t see the magic of this fragrance like other reviewers have.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Phenomenal quality.

Another reviewer below compared this to Terre D'Hermes and they are correct.

This is a beautiful citrus blast; the citrus here is that organic, gritty lemon rind. This is in comparison to say Versace Pour Homme where the citrus is smooth. Both great but very different.

Longevity is excellent, it lasts for hours with only two sprays.

Unisex but slightly masculine leaning.

It's quite linear to me. It hasn't changed much on my skin; the citrus and vetiver are constant.

I strongly recommend this but if you have Terre D'Hermes Eau Givree it might be redundant.

9/10

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Wow, where has this been all my life?

Zingy citrus on a bed of smooth lavender and crispy vetiver, inflected with pink pepper and sage. Aromatic and beautiful in its simplicity, exactly the type of fragrance I enjoy. The ingredients in this smell exceptionally natural, as with all ADP fragrances.

This is understated casual sophistication. I'm headed to Sicily and Portugal in September, and I already know this will be my daily driver on that trip.

This is one of the best in the ADP lineup.

Edit: I'm surprised nodody is mentioning that much-appreciated oak moss in the late stages of the dry down. It's strange that it is not included in the listed notes above, as it's most definitely there.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
It's a vetiver bomb, fresh and citrusy, with a spicy green plant sharpness, spices, grapefruit, and lots of lemon peel. There's also something of propolis and citronella. It's an entire core of vetiver surrounded by sharpness and freshness. Definitely, it's the spiciest and most aromatic in the line, just as Colonia Pura is the most floral. It also tends more towards the masculine side. Especially in its opening, it has a bit of the citrus note from Dior Homme Cologne (probably my favorite citrus note), but Colonia Futura lasts much longer on the skin. It's like Terre d'Hermès with its citrusy vetiver, but replacing the very ripe, almost overripe, orange of Hermès with lemon and lemon peel.

It's the offspring of the original Colonia (light musk, vetiver, bergamot, and moss) and the original Eau Sauvage (sharp lemon, vetiver, moss, vetiver, lemon, and vetiver). As mentioned, vetiver, vetiver, vetiver—earthy and sharp, it even reminds me of string instruments like cellos and violins with their varnished wood (a very pleasant association, actually).

Contrary to the line's reputation, this one lasts for hours on the skin, remaining fresh and sharp. It's a pointed and delicious perfume.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
After depleting my sample, I've got a giant 6oz bottle of Colonia Futura on the way. I've been searching for a natural, citrus forward scent for the mornings, as I love a blast of citrus to rid me of the demons. But not one that hangs around like a demon. Like a bowl of grapefruit or large pour of orange juice to set the day off right.

Although there's no orange in this, it's all lemon with grapefruit playing second fiddle. Very natural, realistic, and non-synthetic citrus which sticks around just barely into the heart. The lavender isn't hairspray like, powdery, or barbershop-y. The vetiver is not smoky or too sharp, but a light, crispy green. This is hard to find!

The herbal, green, and aromatic heart and base sends this into love territory for me. It give this some legs and depth that I feel makes Colonia Futura timeless. Hence the quibbles with the name—this is way more timeless/classic than futuristic, as there are no oddball notes that call to mind what we dream of when we hear the word "future". I do love good synthetic or weirdo notes when used purposefully (think Comme Des Garcons) but there is absolutely nothing synthetic, artificial or futuristic here.

Being purportedly 99% natural ingredients (1% to stabilize the formula according to their website) what does make this feel more modern, (rather than the bombastic base notes of the 70s and 80s) is there is no funky or chemical base that sticks around for ungodly amounts of time. Colonia Futura is a bit softer in projection for it, but longevity is still around 6-8 hours until it almost fully disappears. Most of it's time is spent close to the skin, but a bonus is I do not go anosmic nearly as easy as louder aromachemical driven scents. It also doesn't feature any heavy, dusty, musty, animalic (that I do like in moderation) notes that can turn some gentlemanly classics sour on my skin.

This is a feature and not a bug for me, as I can get a lively spritz in the AM with coffee, and be fully in the clear to wear a different scent in the evening without any interference. Plus, the polite nature of this ensures you will not be known as the person who wears way too much perfume. The flipside of the nuance and more reserved composition is this may come off as uninspired or too middle-of-the-road for those who are fragrance thrill seekers or performance kings/queens. I say queens, because I do think this has gender neutral appeal, for those who like natural perfumery and the listed notes, definitely give this a shot.

Overall, I love this a little more each time I wear it. The citrus opening is bracing (a plus for me) but smoothly gives way for a very satisfyingly simple lavender>sage>vetiver segueway that makes this extremely versatile for any season or occasion. I can't see myself getting sick of this at any point, hence buying a big ole bottle. It makes me feel like I have my life together!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
@Thatbwoy wrote the best review for this entire house and especially this scent.
Props my guy.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura is an interesting name for a scent which doesn’t feel futuristic or modern in the slightest, instead rather demonstrating a very classic and old school fougere scent profile. That’s not a criticism at all however, I actually think the scent is quite beautiful.

The lavender in here is front and centre and smells photorealistic. That sharp green floral aspect is made even sharper by the juicy addition of lemon, bergamot and grapefruit which give it this classical men’s aftershave feel. A touch of dry sage and clean Vetiver round everything out very nicely.

This scent is technically brilliant. If you love classical fougeres this is a must try, especially for the price it can be found at. Albeit a simplistic scent profile, it does this masculine perfume family incredible justice.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: smells like freshly cut grass

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I hold the opinion that this brand is so perfectly positioned and marketed. The type of gentlemen that you assume wear and regularly purchase these fragrances are the type whom the phrase ‘Signature Scent’ accurately typifies. These scents are worn like an extra item of clothing or accessory. Nothing is dominant, all harmonised.

This fragrance is very much that, not outstanding not invasive or brash. Just there like a white pocket square with subtle yellow pin dots. Or like a very plain, very light blue neckerchief worn with a white linen shirt. Imperceptible but present.

I think I like it, but I also am certain I don’t think I care too much about it to wear it again.


Edit:

I wore it again.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Future is just OK. I’m not sure what it is but in the top, I get an apple accord. There are elements of the OG in this fragrance. However, this fragrance is more vetiver forward.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I like citrus fragrances during the summer heat, but this one is so harsh, I can only feel the lemon or lime smell no other notes because the smell of this l bitter lemon are strong.I sprayed few time and people around me looking at me some of them asking what perfume is that, when i told them, they just get quiet without comment...

Longevity 6/10
Sillage 5/10
Projection 5/10
Price 2/10

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: I really like this more naturalistic take on the original. Rather than blended into a soapy freshness the lemon, sage and vetiver all smell like themselves, yet the base of the original is still underneath and reveals itself after a couple of hours. It’s slightly medicinal, but I like that. There is also a salt and mineral quality that isn’t mentioned but makes this feel more oceanic than its brothers, and perhaps some cypress as well to make it extra crisp. No sweetness, little spice no florals either really. Colonia stripped down to its essence and taken to the beach then. It reminds a bit of the Italian minimalism often created by Profumum Roma. Might be my favourite of the line.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I completely get the comparison to eau sauvage but this is so much better in my opinion. Maybe eau sauvage before reformulation? But not the current eau sauvage.
Initial opening has this crisp bright herbaceous citrous punch. Very uplifting and refreshing. After 15 minutes the middle notes come out to play with the top notes. The herbs and spices reveal themselves with a green welcome, a bit of florals too, maybe geranium or a slight light sour rose? Then when it settles and starts to dry down, you feel the lavender and sage wrapping everything so beautifully and set its course on a bedding of vetiver and very faint white musk.

It is a happy scent. I normally don't like old school green scents but this one made me change my mind. I am happy that i have it in my collection. 🤍

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: ThIs is one of my only perfumes I can spray behind my ears and smell for hours. Absolutely love it.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: On the quest for a perfect realistic affordable citrus smell. This has a citrusy spicy sunny opening with light herbaly green feel, as it dries the lavender, sage and vetiver come through. 4.5/5 for realism. ADP Anancina de Capri was too 'room spray' orange, mandorlo was too sweet

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A beautiful scent . A freshly masterpiece! I recommend it if you like lemony and sage perfumes.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Strange no one has mentioned Creed Viking.

As soon as I put it on, that's what I thought of definitely more than eau Sauvage etc. In saying that, the DNA is similar but once the opening notes leave it doesn't resemble Viking as much.
This is like if Viking was a super sport/rock star, had a child who become also a somewhat similar successful career then they had a baby with Eau Sauvages child to create a similar DNA to both but both having different traits of its own, as for becoming a super star this perfume will not become that.

Here's why, this is not a mainstream DNA anymore that era has passed but for those who do like this DNA it will be a great fragrance.

I do really like this and believe this is a friendly more rounded and subdued Viking/Eau Sauvage. I will wear this in the office and I believe it can be versatile. It doesn't scream look at me nor drop kick others in the nose as if Chuck Norris just walked past and didn't like your face.

This is quite a beautiful fragrance, the selling point of 99% natural ingredients well its hard to tell but it does smell of quality and luxury. I got this at a steal of a price, I wouldn't pay retail for it ever. I have been on the fence about this fragrance for a while and glad I got it.

It's in my top 3 from Parma after Mirra & Essenza.

The breakdown:
DNA - 9 - Not unique but well blended
Appeal - 5 - Could go either way depending who you ask. . .
Longevity- 7.5 - Decent on this front
Projection - 6 - sits close to the skin after 10mins, not a bad thing though
Sillage - 7 - Unsure but assume it has a nice sillage
Overall - 7/10
Personal overall 8/10 - Better other there but a nice perfume nonetheless, will I buy another bottle? I guess I'll see when this runs out!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Initial notes:
Please be advised that this is natural ingredients fragrance. That means initial notes are bit harsh with terpenes for a couple of minutes.
Great bitter lemon, nearly tonic with chinchona comes in quickly.

Mid:
Sage, bay leaf, resin, grapefruit pith — slightly in the vein of Terre d’Hermès.

Base:
Very tart vetiver, slightly toasted. Geranium too?

Performance:
Excellent for a cologne in terms of both longevity and projection. Not a particularly strong sillage it seems.

Value:
It’s worth looking around for good offers. Up to 80-100 $/€ differences. I got 180ml for 90€ but saw it in shops for up to 180€.

Meta:
Natural is one buzzword and I like that thought. It feels and smells rustic and a bit unpredictable like nature itself. It is both classic and new/modern at the same time.

Thoughts:
Great summer scent, but good base makes it suitable for both colder and more formal settings too. There are enough hints of oomph for evening wear, but if you insist on sweetness for winter this is not it. It is dry but in the same way that a fruity white wine is normally perfectly dry.

It also seems to avoid most categories, Someone called it a colonia fougère which I thought was quite accurate. Very exciting.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
blind buy

On paper:
In order of appearance: Bergamot. Lemon. Sage. Pepper. Lavender. Grapefruit.

The drydown is citrus, lavender, sage, and a hint of grassy vetiver.
After a while I'm getting thyme. Isn't that interesting and delicious.

Very bright and fresh, all natural scent made for hot weather.
It's powerful and long lasting.

On skin:
It's all still there but It's a more grassy, herbal blend. It seems darker, greener and more interesting. It's the vetiver that's much more prominent!

All in all I'm very happy with this :)

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura is a pleasant, good-quality warm weather scent. A flanker of sorts of Colonia, the focal point of this house, CF can be best described as a cologne-fougère. Featuring a bright, fresh citrus opening and developing into a lavender-led vetiver scent, it is an elegant masculine spring/summer scent.

CF opens with a bright citrus accord, radiantly fresh and reminiscent of Colonia. I get zesty lemon and tart grapefruit in particular. It quickly becomes aromatic thanks to the herbal notes that follow. Lavender is quite prominent for a time, complemented by soft peppery spices, paving the way to the vetiver-dominant drydown.

The vetiver is dry and woody, very aromatic and slightly earthy. The vetiver used here is top-quality, bringing to mind Guerlain Vetiver, the gold standard of vetiver scents. The faded citrus lingers, and this alongside the spices complements the vetiver to perfection. It is aromatic and restorative, but also a wearable, casually elegant scent. It fades to a musky vetiver skin scent. Sillage and longevity are moderate.

Light and fresh for warm weather, CF also has more body and better performance than a classic cologne, making it ultimately transeasonal. An excellent fresh fougère, this is a great everyday masculine scent that is a road less travelled. 4.5/5.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
It's a vetiver bomb, but fresh and citrusy, with a sting of spicy green plant, spices, grapefruit, and lots of lemon peel. Hints of propolis and citronella too. It's a core entirely of vetiver surrounded by spiciness and freshness. It is definitely the spiciest and most aromatic of the line, just as Colônia Pura is the most floral. It also leans more towards the masculine side. Especially upon first spray, it has some of the citrusy notes of Dior Homme Cologne (probably my favorite citrus note), but the Colônia Futura lasts much longer on the skin. It's like Terre D'hermès with its citrusy vetiver but swapping the ripe, almost rotting orange of Hermès for lemon and lemon zest.
A child of the original Colônia (light musk, vetiver, bergamot, and moss) mixed with the original Eau Sauvage (sharp lemon, vetiver, moss, vetiver, lemon, and vetiver).
As mentioned, vetiver, vetiver, vetiver, earthy and spicy, it even reminds one of string instruments like cellos and violins, with their varnished wood (a rather pleasant association, in fact).
Contrary to the line's reputation, this one lasts for hours on the skin, remaining very fresh and spicy.
It's a sharp and delightful fragrance.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This fragrance remind me much of Dior Eau Sauvage edt! Very pleasant & very vintage style! Nice work❤️🇮🇹

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Can't believe ginger is not mentioned as a note in this one! To my nose, this is Eau Sauvage with amped up ginger and the sillage is largely that of ginger too! Decent longetivity for a Colonia flanker.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: I'm wearing Colonia Futura now and I never noticed the salty and green/ galbanum facets... I wish it lasts longer but it's ok as you can overspray til the end of time. Refreshing and sparkling.Summer and spring banger.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Wow east coast USA smells like Northern California again today! Layered Colonia Futura heavy over 1-2 sprays of afnan supremacy incense on skin to complete the NorCal summer fire season vibe. If you own something with smoke &/or vetiver, this layers very very well.

Sending peace to anyone displaced by wildfire 💞

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is literally the only Acqua Di Parma fragrance I like, long term.
Several of their fragrances are nice and pleasant at first but the dry down is always disappointing to me.
I just brought my bottle out of storage for summer and was moved to write a review.

This is a star in that it is not the same-old stank musk base that so many fragrances are.

It is bright, crisp and classy.
Opening is a dry, peppery citrus mix.
Also, seems like there is Angelica or juniper in there but the notes are not listed.
Pretty linear wear, which I appreciate because there’s nothing more disappointing than spraying a perfume, loving the smell, spending a lot of money on a bottle and having it change to a completely different and off-putting dry down and/or lasting note.

Good on ADP for having the guts to release a fragrance that doesn’t smell like vanilla, Tonka, musk, oud or syrup like most.
👍🏻

*I own a few ADP but this is the only one I can actually wear in public.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Citrus, lavender and sage is the heart and soul of this scent. I love it and has been my go-to for summer since it's release because the herbs used here comes off as fresh linen without being soapy. Some herbs such as lavender and rosemary tend to smell like linen and that's what you're gonna smell like wearing this with a bit of citrus.
Definitely worthy of having in your collection if you want clean that's something else than the usual musky aquatic or soapy clean.
If you know ADP by now you know their scents smell very natural and nothing synthetic. Same goes for this one as well which makes that linen smell that much more cozy and calming.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Masculine, mature, old-school... but still a little bit contemporary, not completely dated.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is not eau sauvage or Armani pour home. This is an updated version of ysl pour homme. After two hours the drydown is exactly the same to my nose! Maybe my next purchase, fan of the predecessor!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Black lime which is used for middle East kitchen as spices .

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Very refreshing and up-lifting. Wear this on a warm summers day wearing a crisp shirt, you will be a breath of fresh air for anyone you meet.
If i had to describe this with 3 words:
Invigorating, classy, masculine.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura by Acqua di Parma reminds me of a favorite now discontinued fragrance Clinique Tailoring for Men. Tailoring for Men was a fragrance that was ahead of its time. Tailoring for Men combined citrus with lavender and a hint of Heliotrope. I miss this scent as it had almost tonic-like effect.
Colonia Futura is very close to Tailoring, but a bit more sophisticated. Colonial Futura keeps the bright citrus that is hallmark of Acqua do Parma range. Colonial Futura is crisp, bright and modern thanks in part to the subtle layering of the lavender. I enjoy Colonia Futura.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Opens up as a citrusy vetiver. Imagine Terre d'Hermes with lemon instead of orange, and you have the opening pretty close.

The dry down is more interesting. The lemon fades away and you're left with a fresh green vetiver smell,and pepper. Over time the vetiver starts to fade, which makes the pepper seem more prominent. After 3 hours or so it's basically just a peppery vetiver smell.

It actually lasts a really long time - I could smell it on my skin 12 hours later. The problem is it just doesn't project much after the first couple hours.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I have mixed feelings about this one, on one hand it smells like a modern classic, fresh and woody.
On the other I get a slight smell of manure and I instantly think of all the scents my father wore in the early 90's.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Perfect 11/10

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: "Modern" oldschool cologne. Opening can be harsh. The drydown is very enjoyable. Good longevity, definitely not a screamer in terms of projection. A handsome,gentle, gentleman cologne.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Yes, I expected it to be barbershopy but it relies on lemon way more than I anticipated,it’s a classic,masculine vibe to it but be careful as dry lemony is gonna be the most dominant in the opening and heart notes,dry down is the best part of it IMO.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
According to this uninspiring cologne we are heading towards a very bland and boring future.
Dry tart citrus with green and woody facets, all ‘fun’ of the classic AdP removed, the moss the florals the realism. Mowed lawn and citrus zest, if that sounds nice to you knock yourself out.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Strong violin vibes here, both in the opening and drydown.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is one of my favourite AdP (my very fav is Intensa), I love the citrus, with lavander and sage: very different from the others in the line, very classy and mature.
My only regret is that on my skin sillage is extremely weak, otherwise it would be a big "love" for me, while know it's just a "like".

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Do all violins smell like this, or just yours?

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This smells like the inside of a violin. Yes, I play violin and no I don’t want to smell like that.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very herbal off the top. Very nearly off-putting. Quickly becomes more barbershop and citrusy and pleasant. Doesn't last very long on me. Somewhat disappointing, but the dry down is actually very nice, as short as it lasts. Recommend.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Opens with a strong blast of a kind of green lemon and fastly turns to a very herbal scent.
Does not last , very weak barbershoppy frangrance, the citrus and vetiver reminds me of eau sauvage which I prefer to AdP. What reminds after 3 hours is a far earthy lavender.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
It reminds me a lot of something not very popular called Haze, from Akro.
This is very different from the original Colonia.
It opens citrusy, but that doesn't last long at all; it becomes very herbal very quickly; I also detect something smokey and earthy.
It "calms down" after 1-2 hours to become a mix of vetiver, lavender and sage. It's not sweet at all, but not bitter neither, probably thanks to the lavender.
Just like Akro's Haze, this is an acquired taste, too. It's really not for everyone; I would strongly advise to sample first, unless you've established yourself in the niche world and have an open mind.
AdP has finally taken some risk, and they delivered, imo.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
ADP Colonia Futura. Old World vibe with New World facets. Think fresh barbershop cologne with lavender, citrus and a subtle clean, light soap and vetiver nuance. If you like a little bit of that throwback vibe of lavender & oak moss similarities of yesteryear with a nice infusion of citrus & florals of today, this one must be sampled. Not for everyone and I strongly suggest not blind buying. Under 30? Suspect at best. Over that, seriously consider it as a solid fresh cologne with better that average longevity. Sillage & projection are not its strong points but, with enough sprays you will catch gorgeous wafts of this scent all day.

They nailed it, regardless of the naysayers and ill perceived fragrance pundits that downplay this fragrance and what it represents. Most of them can’t tell the difference between their ass and a hole in the ground, let alone what in today’s mindset of existence of what should or should not be considered class & modern day sophistication if they have no clue or semblance of self. Fools really and a pity.

Don’t fear this creation and enjoy it for what it is. An homage to the past with delightful modern day traits for yesterdays & today’s man.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is a great scent, clean and fresh, but, has poor projection and sillage, on longevity I get approx 6 hours.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Blind bought a big bottle full presentation for under $60. Best blind buy to date, this is about to become my warm weather signature. The note tree is broken but so is my nose. I have a hard time with vetiver, it comes and goes like an aromachem for me. Lavender in frags just smells “ubiquitously clean”. To me this is:

Live herbs in a pine forest, real citrus rind
Sage & herbs
SAGE live and pumping in the sun & soil

Lived in the sierra foothills of CA for a bit & this instantly takes me back to swimming in big Chico creek late August surrounded by sage, foxtail (dry golden grass) & manzanita. The scent of the pine forest up the hill washing down with the cold mountain water.

This frag is eternity EDP with the apple dropped, little citrus added & then classed up. Performance is pretty good on me, 6+ hours on moisturized skin. Sprayer is actually a mister which takes a few sprays to get right. Quality. Same quality in the bottle. Very nice presentation.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: I started very critically with this one, but it has now grown on me to the point that I’m wearing it more than anything else. A fantastic green scent.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Not a clone but think vetiver-forward Viking. Definitely a grower if you enjoy smelling dapper.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I have now rated 200 fragrances and of those, Colonia Futura is currently my number 1. Maybe I'm still on a honey moon with this, but it's the only fragrance I've ever bought where I am already sorry I didn't buy the big bottle. Only one. I never buy the big bottles, but I hate to see this bottle getting empty, yet I crave to spray this especially in the evenings.

Lavender, vetiver and citruses, all top of the class. Clean, natural, fresh, invigorating, bracing, classy, manly, beautiful. Lasts for many hours too, which is great for an all-natural cologne.

It's almost like a paradigm shift to me: since this is so perfect for me, should I look at natural perfumery next?

Edit: The perfumer is none other than Francois Demarchy himself.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Vintage Eau Sauvage!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This smells exactly like the aftershave my late father used to use in the 80s/90s. Not very contemporary and nothing groundbreaking either. For me personally, it’s a bit heavy on the vetiver. I did enjoy the opening though. Either way, there are better and more interesting offerings from Acqua di Parma.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Woody vetiver bomb with some citruses. This is nice but I prefer my vetiver much more complex and earthy like in Sultan Vetiver.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura?? More like Colonia Pasta… If “99% all-natural ingredients” is futuristic, weren't all perfumes 100% natural until the IFRA started banning the natural stuff? Whatever. Either way, the name is way off from what this is: Masculine vetiver citrus as traditional as it gets! The sage comes to the fore after the beautiful lemon opening. I rate the sage as the strongest note in the late opening/mid. Dry, sun-sweetened sage in full glory. It’s quite bracing and smells natural. The citrus hangs around in the background longer than I expected, and of course the vetiver comprises the lingering base. This is a pungent, sharp vetiver- nothing smoky or earthy at all.
Futura is a simple, natural, beautiful Italian men’s fragrance. If you enjoy classics like Chanel Pour Monsieur, Loewe Pour Homme, or Eau Sauvage, I can’t imagine you wouldn’t love this. Perhaps the perfumers at ADP have not learned from the past and are doomed to repeat it. For those of us who love this kind of fragrance, Ignorance is bliss.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: oh my, i love this! very lemony over a warm, earthy, and slightly spicy vetiver base (also some discrete patchouli to my nose.) this will be my summer perfume (together with miller harris citron citron, another, albeit fresher and drier, lemon-vetiver beauty.)

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: @Grownassedman: Thanks for the heads up!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
@grownassedman: Good to know. Didn't realised I'd missed the boat on Club, which I've had my eye on for a while, but I'm happy to hear that they've replaced it with something - will look into C.L.U.B., since you make it sound good too, if different.

Futura is pretty green, isn't it? Very citrus heavy at the beginning - I get a lot of grapefruit in particular. But the dry down is very much dominated by the sage and vetiver, to my nose.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Natural-smelling fougere centered around vetiver, that also lasts longer than "eau de cologne" would indicate. I love it, though that may be because I'm a fan of green aromatic scents before the citrus-focused ones that AdP is known for. I have a hard time finding long-lasting fragrances appropriate for hot weather (taking suggestions!) - this will do in the meantime!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: @ts01 yup.. this one and that Le Labo one. This one is better, but still even the lady at the counter agreed about the pickles note. Went with the Colonia Club instead, but will try this one again in the future.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: That’s two different perfumes where you’ve said they smell like pickles. Could be something else going on here man.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Futura is very much a well thought-out, smooth vetiver scent, so not your traditional colonia based on citrus or soapy neroli notes.

The opening is a bit misleading and comes across as really harsh. In fact I’m not even sure the citrus in the opening does the overall fragrance much justice. Luckily that aspect doesn’t last.

Once the heart notes start pumping out, the fragrance smooths considerably and turns very green. The sage and lavender provide this part which is where things turn quite pleasant to my nose. There is also the gentlest of sweetness at this point supported with a faint hint of woodiness below it. It stays very green. In fact by this point, you may wonder if you’re dressed in camouflage or lying in a herb patch.

The vetiver enters with some moss, but these aspects simply underpin the green sage and lavender accord which sits on top throughout. The whole accord makes for a herbaceous, aromatic green scent.

I can’t wait to put this on in the warmer months, but even in the winter it has proved unique, vibrant and uplifting. In my opinion it’s everything that the hash-up known as Colonia Club should have been. My faith in AdP may just be restored with this scent.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is a Fragrance for those with taste. When I was new into fragrances I disliked this, I preferred mainstream brands like invictus or sauvage. Now when I smell this I enjoy it. It smells classy, refined and definitely sophisticated. If you are looking for compliments don’t buy this. This will instead get you recognised as a classy, clean and sophisticated man.

As for the smell it smells fresh and citrusy mixed with pepper. The vetiver comes in the dry down as it settles.
Longevity isn’t bad but it doesn’t project for that long, I’d give it an hour/ hour half projection.
Buy this on discount, it is overpriced to be bought otherwise.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Very elegant, mature and "old fashioned", but in a good way.
I could describe it as a bitter version of the original Drakkar (not "Noir", but the one from the seventies). Only the people of 45 and over will be able to appreciate this cologne.
It is a very formal, office scent, that is well suited for warm and hot weather during daytime.
Sillage, projection and longevity are average; but the quality of the very natural smell is excellent.
Because of the performance, I find it overpriced; but I'd buy it again for its beauty and similarities with the fragrances of my childhood (during the seventies).

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: I tried this one in a hot summer day and I got hooked. No other circus scent has gave me the same vibes. It's very shinny and uplifting. The best citrus scent during my journey. A great release from the house.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Baby Tsar(van Cleef and arpels) Love it. Tsar is 45+. This is 35+

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: 25-Female. I smelled this at Nieman Marcus and after spraying the tester paper just 2x, I immediately recognized an aroma that I love so deeply: oakmoss. I'm very new to the niche Perfume world and have tried now about 50-60 perfume niche samples up to this point, so im still learning about scent "profiles" and notes, but several years ago I discovered oil perfumerie "For Strange Women" (earthy, animalic, antique and witchy type scents) and without knowing the whole ordeal in the Perfume world about oakmoss, I fell in love with it in FSW's scents (see: November in the Temperate Deciduous Forest which features mushroom, oakmoss, etc.) So naturally I have been trying whatever niche perfumes I come by that feature oakmoss in the formulation and I thought that this one would be a fave in my "fougere" stock because it smelled so wonderful in store, but I bought a bottle secondhand and while officially wearing it on the skin, it seems to really be lacking something. After 5-10 mins, the crisp citruses are gone and I'm left with a very weak oakmoss scent (very sad). I really don't think my skin composition pulls out the Vetiver very much because I have a few Vetiver scents and this one bares no resemblance to them. Someone in the reviews compared it a bit to TF Grey vetiver (which i love) and i personally cannot pick up any similiarities between the two. Colonia Futura could have had a lot of potential, but for me (could be my body chemistry), it falls very flat. It doesn't eminate from my skin beyond a couple inches after 20minutes of wear, and it seems to lack a lot of depth you'd think it would have based on the notes. It's definitely a very light "fougere/chypre" which makes it wearable for those intimidated by the typically bold and intense earthy scents that define these profiles. I also don't find this terribly masculine as others said. It's crisp, light, and a tad earthy which could fit anyone depending on what you like. Anyway, I had higher hopes for this one, expecting a heart of rich oakmoss, but its honestly disappointing. I'll still use it, but only for the purpose of not wasting it. I have many other perfumes that do what this can't. Several of my oil perfumes from For Strange Women definitely trump this one by far.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Persolaise interviewed Paola Paganini from Acqua Di Parma on his YouTube channel and she briefly discussed Colonia Futura. (She is so charming!) She says it's all naturally derived fragrance compounds and quite specifically a project by Acqua Di Parma to pursue sustainable fragrance based on naturals, the old fashioned way. So I bought it blind. The ingredients even include OAKMOSS.

Well it smells great and not like anything I know today. Futura is rustically bracing and reminds me of something very fresh and fragrant but certainly NOT a designer fragrance. Possibly a bug spray or scented soap from my youth. A hippy might enjoy this. I wouldn't say its a simple composition rather its uncomplicated smelling and a bit like Italian and especially Spanish cologne splashes - those big bottles one can buy in supermarkets to use in summer months or after a bath. I can imagine this being rejected by many noses today. Or some might feel its not worth the price, in comparison to those budget cologne waters. My nose adjusts quickly nowadays so I like this for now. Wait and see if that likability endures. The opening alone rewards any effort to experience it. Don't pass up the opportunity to spray this on if you see it at the fragrance counter. Also, Futura surely can be something to spray onto another fragrance that lacks a dynamite top.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
To me it smells like the bottle’s colors, pleasant citrusy spicy sunny opening with light herbaceous green feel, as it dries the lavender sage vetiver taking the show in a citrusy spicy nature , simple classic, a colognia that fresh with cosiness and a layer of warmth, a modern “classic” italica that never forgets the roots,
Nothing very new but a pleasant Cologne, unisex leaning masculine gentleman side. Could fit all year. Reminds me of Uomo by Lorenzo.
Edit, also in the same realm of terre d’hermes and Viking Cologne, especially the citrusy pepperness conjugate with vetiver.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: @ Luciak Look into Mirto di Panerea as it is one of the most unisex from ADP (well-blended myrtle and rose notes), perhaps leaning slightly feminine.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Grassy Vetiver with that signature Colonia opening. Citrus is short lived and vetiver is what i get after 5-10 mins of spraying the fragrance. Slightly powdery green notes with clean vetiver. Quality is top notch just like every other ADP. For me this one was not something special. It has a slight resemblance to TF Grey Vetiver in the composition of the fragrance but TF smells a bit modern and retains its freshness for a longer time. Surely try this if you are a vetiver lover.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Hello - wondering if I can get an opinion on Acqua di Parma fragrances for a first time buyer (woman fragrance or unisex that leans feminine)- which one would you recommend?

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Futura - a fragrance from the future ! Put that in your pipe and smoke it !

Thing about classic Italian sci fi though - it was never very good lol :)

If this didn't have Parma quality (which it does) it would be trash bin food. As it is Futura isn't bad. Think of it as nonsense written with a gold pen on the finest paper. And some days you will feel funny in the head and then this will pop out from your wardrobe.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
As much as i like the various offerings of Acqua di Parma (Colonia Assoluta and Intensa being my favourites), this Futura is quite 'meh'.
Forget the pyramid as it has been displayed above: no big citrus, no bergamot and no pepper detectable here.

Futura is a vetiver fragrance, with grass, fir and juniper all along.
In a word, a light fougere.
It is indeed green and refreshing, but not a cuddly drydown nor calming as its siblings are.
It is dry. Like a phrase Hemingway would write.

Very masculine (i really cannot pull it off, and bear in mind that in summer with these torrid temperatures I sustain mainly on fresh cologne, even masculine ones), as I said vetiver takes the lead front end to back end.

Longevity nil. Sillage... in your bubble, for half an hour.
To me, a huge pass.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Opens with bold lemon. Dry down seems to have some eucalyptus but the lemon doesn't totally fade. Much prefer Colonia Pura to this. Really wanted to like it for environmental reasons but it's not really at the level of the top ADP and others.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
It’s nice...but nothing really unique. On my skin, I get a vetiver dominant scent. If you really enjoy ADP’s beautiful citrus openings, this one might let you down. It’s pretty earthy from the start.

Opens with a gentlemanly soft citrus. As it dries down, the spicy lavender/vetiver takes over. As it dries down more, if becomes a soft earthy vetiver scent. Gentlemanly, professional vibe…not really a casual scent.

Longevity was 6/7 hours on me. Projection is average. Certainly masculine and one could rock this year round...although best for warmer months.

Overall, it’s not bottle worthy for me. It’s nice...but I already own a few fragrances that do what this does. I’ll enjoy my healthy decant...but that’s about it.

4/2/22 UPDATE - broke down and bought a bottle…the struggle is real😂😂😂

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
maybe the name "futura" is not the best, the fragrance in itself is nothing really new, but i have to say this is a different take on the a.d.p. colonia line, more green and herbal, and the most important thing to point out is....futura smells AMAZING!. fantastic opening with bergamot, lime and grapefruit. the drydown is great with a beautiful lavender and, most of all, vetiver. the note of vetiver is the protagonist of the drydown and i understand the comparison between terre d'hermes(edt and intense vetiver) and futura. t.d.h. in my opinion has a better performance, but futura is definitely more natural smelling. both are great, but futura has that italian gentleman vibe with a soft "sense of humor", it's not too serious and formal. i love this scent, one of my favourite of the a.d.p. line, and the price of the tester is very affordable. performance is good, slightely above average: good projection in the first 1,5 hour, then more silent. longevity about 6-7 hours, not bad for a summer scent. for casual and formal situations, for a well dressed man over 30. glad to have it in my collection!
acqua di parma futura ha un nome altisonante, forse non porta niente di futuristico ma bisogna dire che è un pò diverso dalle colonie della stessa linea e soprattutto odora divinamente! mix riuscitissimo di bergamotto, lavanda e vetiver, tutto molto naturale e ben orchestrato. non per giovanissimi, io non lo sono e quindi ci sto a pennello. ottimo acquisto!

scent-9
longevity-7,5
sillage-7,5
uniqueness-7,5
versatility-8
presentation-6,5
back up bottle?maybe
compliment factor-7

my vote-8,5

in one word- exquisite

alternative- terre d'hermes edt and intense vetiver.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Smells very Mediterranean to me. Opens very zingy fresh. Mid is a extremely elegant sage note in combination with vetiver. Deep drydown is oakmoss (much loved and missed!!).
A very intoxicating summer gem. I plan to use it this summer in mid Dalmatia where it will be perfect. Staying power is amazing considering it being a edc, and yes you can go overboard with the sprayer as it never becomes overbearing. A new take on many scents from the past but this time THAT is the wonder of it.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This a quite a departure from standard AdP DNA - on my skin the opening is a very warm Pink Pepper & icy smooth Vetiver punch with a herbal and fresh grapefruit background… smells like somewhere between Creed’s Viking and Penhaligon’s greener fragrances. The dry down reminds me of a fresher, herbal infused Terre d’ Hermes. Not bad at all - definitely for the over-40s male at an informal party on a late Spring afternoon/evening. Decent projection for a few hours and decent staying power - remains as a faint skin scent the next morning.

Reminds me of the opening of TFs Beau de Jour.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Really nice, cant stop smelling my arm. Fresh and woody, and natural. No artificial notes. Makes me think about camping in a forest, or firewood drying in the sun.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
No Oak Moss on the listed notes?, even though its shown on the ingredient label and
clearly identifiable in the drydown.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Well... very reminiscent of a spa.
the smell of the lavender is superb with mixed notes of citrus.
a real image of a laundry room and the spa rooms - the smell of the laundry is a picture I have in my mind
perfect for spring/Summer (not to sure about cooler months)
very reminiscent of Neal yard orange and Geranium hand cream
7/10
it does have that barbershop feel but that goes quickly into a warm relaxing scent
a down side of this fragrance is the undertone of hot cross buns, doesn't sit well.

better on clothes than skin...believe me

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Fresh and invigorating citrus with a hint of tomato leaves in the beginning. It’s one of those fragrances that make seeing the light in dark places an easier task. But seeing the future? In the end it’s a citrusy vetiver, why the pompous name!

It’s a nice cologne. But I don’t find it adding anything new, let alone futuristic, to my quite vast collection of superior colognes.
***(**)

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Acqua di Parma Colonia Futura is the latest in the Colonia range. It takes a slightly different turn to most of the recent ones. It opens with a projection that is moderate for the first 60 - 90 minutes before becoming a skin scent and lasts somewhere between six and seven hours in total.

Acqua di Parma Colonia Futura opens with a burst of vetiver, sage, lavender, lemon and grapefruit. I wouldn't say there's any bergamot and I never got any pink pepper at any point. It opens as a herbal citrus. 20 minutes in it becomes noticeable that the vetiver is a very earthy one, and a dry earthy one at that. 25 minutes in and the lemon and grapefruit top notes are fading fast and the vetiver is the clear dominant note. Around two and a half hours in you have a herbal core sitting on top of the dominant vetiver with a tiny bit of grapefruit on top, all with a very intimate sillage. It fades significantly so that four hours in you have to smell your arm directly in order to smell the perfume. It lingers for another two to three hours.

This one goes well layered with Acqua di Parma Colonia Assoluta in Villa where the latter's cypress in the woody notes offsets the dryness of the earthy vetiver in Colonia Futura, and the spices and flowers in Assoluta in Villa give it a brighter, more balanced, more nuanced effect while staying resolutely traditional.

You can also layer it well with Acqua di Parma's Chinotto di Liguria. There is a brightness and bitterness that works well by combining the chinotto with the lemon and grapefruit at the top; the geranium, jasmine and cardomom work together and complement each other well in the heart notes; and the patchouli and musk add depth and richness to the base without drowning out the vetiver. Again, this combination remains resolutely traditional.

You could also layer it with AdP Bergamotto di Calabria to give it a dose of bergamot led freshness at the top and warmth in the middle but it can be a bit hit and miss depending on how you get along with the flowers and ginger. Nevertheless, the effect of the citron in Bergamotto di Calabria really enhances the opening of Colonia Futura and takes it in a different direction.

In short, Colonia Futura works much better when you combine it with something that enhances one of its main aspects.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Starts off as Creed Viking with an ADP twist and dries down to a very herbal base. Not my favourite, 2/5

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is not unisex perfume. Very spicy, very like an old man.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is 100% vetiver and nothing else, if you really smell it then maybe you get some citrus notes the first minute. But after that it's just vetiver and very strong eye watering vetiver.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Hard to say that futura is part of the colonia range. So much more harbal notes, and for me it's a nice, beautiful vetiver fragrance. I actually smell an aromatic tea leaf note which is a good blend of the notes above, I like to take it this way and forget about the sage. My nose would love more lavender instead.
Performance is good, last longer than any from the family, and silage is slightly better as well. It's nice and fresh, clean and airy, if you into vetiver this is a must. If you love the citrusy, soapy original colonia don't risk a blind buy on futura. Worth a try though. This is a VETIVER parfume!

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A very close approximation of 'Pour Monsieur' by Chanel on my skin. Lovely, fresh citrus and green top notes burst out from the first spray, then dry down within an hour to a typically woody/musk phase that becomes a skin scent within a couple of hours.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I like the concept of a fragrance made of 99% natural ingredients. I bought a bottle and really wanted to like this it and be my go to Acqua Di Parma. Unfortunately it is not as nice as the original Colonia, Essenza, Pura, or Intensa.

It is very herbal: the sage is very present throughout and almost overbearing. If you like herbal fragrances this would be great but is quiet a step away from Colonia (soapy, classic) Essenza (Neroli twist on the Colonia) Pura (more floral with ozonic notes) or Intensa (more woody with leather).

I did wear it just a few days and somehow I feel that it is too underwhelming. It doesn't make you smell great or soapy/clean so if you are planning to blind buy I would say don't do it. If you are looking for a floral, nice and modern one I would go with Colonia Pura. Of course the classic Colonia is a great option too. Both blind buys for me but not in this case. Some previous reviews mention this being more for an old/man or woman. I don't think this is the issue here: is really the herbal/sage taste that would be a turn off to many people.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: A worthy variation on the theme of AdP’s Colonia. The opening is more similar to the original than to Essenza, but it is more astringent and slightly bitter. Lemon, grapefruit, and bergamot dominate in the first several minutes. As the astringent opening mellows, clary sage mingles with the bitter grapefruit notes to create something special. The blend of bitter and herbal notes almost suggests black licorice, as interpreted by AdP. Lavender is present, but not overpowering. Over time, the citrus fades and a restrained vetiver joins the mix. I like it more every time I wear it. It’s like a less powdery Colonia or Essenza without the neroli. Not groundbreaking, but compelling nonetheless.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: It carries the original Colonia DNA infused with like at least 3x times more Sage, but why?! I think it is definitely overdone deceiving your attention from the rest of the notes, and does not work that well as perfume but has rather some home spray or even church spray effect (if that is even a thing)

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Absolute piece of garbage.
Avoid.
Take a very diluted and stale lemonade that would have been left on a counter for a week or two.
I don t say that lightly as i have a lot of scents (around 150) and a lot of ADP that i love.
I got one of the first ones from Sephora.
Total trash.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
While I respect the opinions posted about this new ADP offering (everyone is welcomed to their opinions about how something smells), I do not understand the dislikes or even the comparisons to TDH. This is one of the most (if not THE most) natural smelling, clean, aromatic, well-balanced colognes I have ever had the pleasure to use (and yes, I'm a Creed fanboy). Citrus-salty sparkling opening, incredible incense-like lavender-herbal middle, and a deliciously "smokey" vetiver note at the end of a beguilingly well-developed offering from ADP. This fragrance is a classic case of great ingredients working synergistically to create something where the sum is greater than the parts.
And, while leaning towards being a skin scent, this stuff still has considerable saying power. It does not, however, scream at folks when you enter the room. I LOVE smelling this relaxing yet energizing scent; and have received a number of compliments on it. Plus, because of the amazing mixture of notes and dry down, it's a year-round scent. This is not *like* ADP's other colognes -- except in a distant cousin sort of way. I got a big bottle of it, and I'm about 95% sure that within the next 12 months, it'll be drained out from being sprayed. It's. Just. That. Good.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
@knoxknoll777

Colonia futura does not remind Terre d'Hermes at all. Futura is is like light and metallic version of "vetivery" barbeshop. It's herbal and its citruses are yellow and green, not orange like TdH. Terre is way much dirtier, more soily and contain that dusty iso-E super thing...

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I think it is good - not great.
I believe if you could get it at a discount and not pay retail, it would be an ok purchase. It sort of reminds you of TDH but a little lighter. If you already on that, it would be a redundant purchase in my opinion. If you don't and can get it for roughly the same price of TDH, I would say go for this.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: You would think, from the "old man smell" comments, that a lot of fragrance enthusiasts work in retirement homes...

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: I was so dissapointed when I tested this. Smells like an old man. I will revisit it in the future, perhaps it suits me better then.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Wow - I tried this today at Harrods and really loved it. I can be quite difficult with my perfumes, especially with fresh citrusy perfumes and particularly with some of the AdP perfumes. But this one surprised me. In spite of my already ridiculously huge perfume collection, this one has a given spot in the fresh-herbaceous category.
It's composed of three overlapping accords that perfectly tie into and reinforce each other. First accord is the citrus top note. A perfect marriage of bergamot, grapefruit, lemon with a hint of pepper to spice things up. The top note is really well balanced and not too sweet, leaving a slight bitterness at the end. Then the heart is made up the dynamic duo of clary sage and lavender. Here the the herbaceous notes perfectly merge with the bergamot to add some depth to the volatile citrus notes, almost pulling the citrus down and together whilst also lifting up the woody earthy accord that makes up the base of the perfume. Out of all the perfumes that I have tried so far this year, this is one of the best. It is an outstanding perfume and remarkably balanced. Worth trying.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I was very excited to try this out and went to my local place where they had a tester and the gentleman there kindly went upstairs, opened the tester and told me i was the first to try it. Let me preface this by saying iv'e had bottles of club (too minty for me), essenza (perfectly nice), intensa (very masculine and got a bit cloying after a while) and lastly the Pura which is a favourite weekend scent to chill out in. ironically never wanted to buy the original colonia.

Futura started out with a blast of mint at first, and was very fresh and citrusy. And I liked it, it then evolved into a much deeper and complex fragrance with some woods and although not listed, i get vetiver. Right now sniffing arm i can tell you its a very classic, refined and elegant fragrance, perhaps to my mind geared to the older (the touch of lavender is that association, to my nose anyway). All in all not for me (i'll stick with the pura) but its still very nice, classy and sure to do well.

product_name: Colonia Futura Acqua di Parma
review_content: Not had a sniff, yet.....but when the number of votes for longevity and sillage are different, then something is amiss. Does it really smell like G.I.Joe...? Two people have already smelled Colonia Futura and say it smells like G.I.Joe. Would someone who gets to preview AdP really know about G.I.Joe or even admit to it...? Come on Fragrantica, you can do much better than this - only allow votes on sillage and longevity if you have written a review - too many trolls or even paid for shills operating on the site.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: I am writing this review to prevent you from doing the same mistake as I did. This is an OK perfume, nothing groundbreaking but that's not the problem, why the heck was this called OSMANTHUS? It has nothing to do with the natural gorgeous smell of the plant. To my nose it's a simple inoffensive GENERIC fruity floral composition that doesn't worth the name OSMANTHUS. Please pm me if you have a real feminine osmanthus suggestion <3

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: smells more floral neroli and orangish fresh opening. I don't pick up osmanthus at all. It is fine tho i would wear this but I bought this expecting osmanthus and I don't get it

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content:
i don't know real osmanthus scent.

At first it smells fine. It's fine floral.
But soon after there smells something unpleasant animalic scent. If it's osmanthus, i don't like osmanthus.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: The green mandarin at the opening is fresh and pretty, but it fades quickly and the neroli becomes dominant (not a good thing for me as I don’t love neroli). I love both ambrette and patchouli but I’m not getting much of either one—mostly a fresh white floral similar in my mind to many designer offerings. It’s nice, and I could see people being perfectly happy with it, it’s just not for me.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Disgusting 🤢

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: To me, this is unique. I haven't found a similar floral and fruity combination. It is pleasant and wearable, but also nothing too impressive. Very safe. I think it could be a signature scent for people who want to play it extremely safe.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smelled this at an airport in Italy in 2023 Nov. it was on my wish list for months and I finally got it. Such a lovely floral fragrance. Although it is quite feminine in a way, I wear it a lot as a guy. It’s one of the only feminine scents I actually wear a lot. It brings my mood up. I just wish it lasted and projected.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is a mild fruity floral for young peeps. The titular osmanthus (which smells like apricots) is only detectable at the very end of the scent's development, so the name is kinda misleading. The fragrance lasts a fair bit, but its projection is abysmal - literally half an hour after application it turns into a skin scent. Not worth the money.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Fruity floral musk, synthetic and generic, can't detect any osmanthus.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: wow, i tested this on my hand and i told my friends "this kind of smells like green mandarin" before looking at the notes lol. the florals reminds me of a kind of subdued daisy by marc jacobs. i am not good at identifying floral notes so I apologize if that is a weird comparison. I'm definitely getting a white gummy bear scent as well lol. i quite like it, but you would think it would have some longevity at this price point. i believe it lasted no longer than 3 hours.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Aqua di Parma’s Osmanthus EDP is a beautiful, light, aethereal, sweet floral with strong fruity nuances and a subtle spiciness.

The star of the show for me is as expected the osmanthus flower, combined closely together with peony, pink pepper and a very bright mandarine. The ambrette creates a soft, velvety base, together with a clean patchouli leaf. Everything is very smooth, flawlessly blended and perfectly balanced.


It’s perfect for spring and summer season and smells very pretty and feminine. Is it worth the hefty price tag though? Not quite sure because of how it performs. Yes, patchouli in the base usually helps fragrances with longevity, which is moderate for this scent, but sits close to the skin. It’s an intimate scent but nonetheless very beautiful!

I am sold if I could get it for a decent price that would match in my mind the mediocre performance!

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Lacks body and falls a bit flat. There are light florals and sugary sweetness on top and an amberwoody/musky/patch base but nothing in between to connect these poles so the scent comes off diluted and poor with a dominating earthy muskiness. Initially I also get a hint of halitosis.
Not bad but nothing special either, especially considering the price. Recommend sampling first.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: I don’t like the mandarin on first spray. It’s green and smells slightly fecal on my skin. Luckily it doesn’t last long and fades to a really pretty floral/apricot scent. Not worth the price tag having to go through half an hour of something I don’t like before it gets good.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Underwhelming for me, not worth the price tag, smells like neroli & peony soap of sorts? like fabric softener, not a fan

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Really nice osmanthus note, and I still get the house DNA, but it's too short-lived to get excited about. They should fix performance issues.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I like this one! It's a lovely floral, but like many of the scents I have tried from this brand, it does not last long.

Nice and fresh smelling but would require too many touch ups over the course of one day.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: I am obsessed with Acqua di Parma. I got my s/o Sandalo and I’ve been trying to collect Acqua di Parmas different scent offerings ever since. I like Osmanthus. It’s an aquatic floral, citrus scent with pink pepper to add that bit of spice to make things interesting. I think it leans feminine but I know some young men who wear it and it smells amazing on them too. It is interesting enough to not be boring, but inoffensive enough for a variety of palettes

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Pleasant enough, but lacking the airiness that I’ve come to expect of osmanthus. I tried this and Yuzu from the same brand. This was initially softer and nicer but the Yuzu developed better over time while Osmanthus simply faded. I wouldn’t spend £250 on this, I would probably prefer the l’Occitane Osmanthus or Shay and Blue White Peaches. It’s a little harder to say no to the Yuzu but maybe a little decant for a treat?

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: How does this have such a low review number? This is a stunning floral scent. One of the ways AdP shines brightest. Soft Osmanthus touched with neroli and patchouli, it is an acquired floral. Very sophisticated smelling. I purchased a sample of this and immediately had to get a full bottle. It is truly a beautiful and unique scent.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Fresh apricot with a little bit of orange and watery pear, a touch of green, plus light floral notes. A very apricot-forward osmanthus that has a vague shampoo-like cleanliness to it and no leather accord. Soft initial projection strengthens slightly over the first hour and fades back over 2-3hr, longevity 5-6hr.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: very fresh! imidiate scent i got was floral pione but not in a heavy obstructing way, so soft and sweet. like seeing a medow out the window and sensing its smells. white floral heavy, the orange note goes strong for a few seconds and then dissapears. i love it. very clean girl coded but at the same time with the perfect amount of soft pillow princess vibes.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Beautiful summer floral. It’s the PERFECT “fresh out of the shower” scent. It smells like an expensive hand soap you put in the guest bathroom and forbid any members of the household from using. Unfortunately it lasts about as long as actually being fresh out of the shower or the scent of hand soap. I wish I could justify the price but I feel like needing to reapply every hour or two would mean spending $300 on a bottle I’d run out of in a month.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content: Really nice wearable floral. On my skin, the osmanthus goes in more of an apricot direction (rather than any leather). Distinctive enough to not be a generic (boring) designer wear, but safe enough to wear on any occasion.

product_name: Osmanthus Eau de Parfum Acqua di Parma
review_content:
