-as the scent dries down, it becomes more refined & I pick up on a rose-vanilla-soft wood accord that significantly (but not entirely) calms down that "dried paint/fish oil" accord

Perspective#1
-on the niche fragrance scale of agreeable to disagreeable,this veers closer to the agreeable side
-so it has a certain appeal to someone who is looking for a unique & signature scent that can still be perceived as friendly, albeit unusual at times

Perspective#2
-have no clue if it's real ambergris in this fragrance; is this just a marketing ploy by the house?
-if there's real ambergris in here, is it responsible for that unique "dried paint/fish oil" accord that has an underlying warm sweetness to it? If so, you can say that you now have exposure to what real ambergris can smell like and how much it can differ from ambroxan

Perspective#3
-ultimately, the scent can come off as linear - the smell doesn't go through perceptible twist and turns
-therefore, it forces you to decide if you like that mixture of the 2 accords (dried paint/fish oil accord VERSUS the rose-vanilla-soft wood accord)
-it's an EDC and so it always has soft projection AND yet it's long-lasting and can regularly be perceived throughout a FULL day's wear; this is a good thing because if this was a projection monster, the unusual nature of the smell would veer away from "artistic restraint and refinement" to obnoxious aggressiveness

One more thing: this comes off better when you are in open/outside environments - there is a soft aura this scent creates around you that mixes well with fresh/open air.

YT channel - The Scentrovert

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
First smell, its very sweet, but not in vanilla way, but its like a sweet grandpa hug, or kinda big old furniture shop, and it reminds me of something 80's or 90's?
Its nice tho, guess im gonna hug a man who use this warm sweet cologne :D
The sweetness its like a unisex perfume, i think better use it at night, coz its warm scent

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Like a store of wooden furniture in the south, the air is humid, and i enter the Store, AC is on and i see good antique Wooden stuff that has been found in the ocean. It is ambra, Sweet, marine, animalic, dirty, yet classy and non offensive. On the contrary of some other reviews i don’t find it synthetic.To love this, first you need to understand the ambergris (Ambra is not about amber!)..takes a while. The presentation is fantastic, and the flacon is also beautiful. But there’s just one criticism; the cap is Unnecessarily too tight That made me unintentionally take out the cover of the atomizer..longevity is indeed satisfying and sillage is quite normal. 7/10

review_content: 很多人說這隻香水充滿了濃濃的男性荷爾蒙，作為一個個子不到160的女生，Ambra卻是我的最愛之一。怎樣一種愛呢？癡迷。噴上身後不停嗅吸與自己的體溫融合的味道，非常純粹的味道。不需要去仔細辨別自己都聞到了哪些原料，只知道濃墨重彩的龍涎香加皮革的組合不斷延續。如果它是一位男士，那可是相當沈穩厚重。

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: It’s so warm. It emphasizes the heat radiating from my body, as if my skin is warmer where I applied it. It got the Colonia zesty freshness but it's also surprisingly musky, dirty musky, almost too much for me after I overdosed on Marlou Poudrextase. However it makes it more alive than Colonia Oud and Colonia Quercia.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Salty, leathery amber.

Strong, loud, & woody. Has a luxurious & mature feeling to it.

The leather is as strong as the amber. Could've easily been called "Amber Leather" or something of that sort, despite the lack of leather in the notes pyramid.

Honestly, not something I'd enjoy wearing personally. This is more +40 years kind of fragrance.

Like.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is a beautiful ambergris-centered fragrance. There are different qualities of ambergris - and different concentrations of tincture - and I wouldn't be surprised if they used real tincture of black ambergris (lower quality), since they specify "ambergris tincture" in the note list. If not, I would guess they at least used the higher-end ambergris-like molecule (IFF's Ambergris T. Olifacc), since the smell here does not look like the cheap and sharp usual ambergris aromachemicals (ambroxan, cetalox or cachalox) you can find in many designer frag (ie. Dior Sauvage)

It opens beautifully with the typical citrusy-woody AdP signature blast, and then morphs quickly on a sharp ambergris supported by a hint of rose.
The drydown is still ambergris focused, but it gets rounded by a noticeable sandalwood note and a blend of labdanum and vanilla.

This one shares strong similarities with Colonia Oud in the drydown, with a fresher profile (ambergris).
As for performance, I previously read that some reviewers were disappointed, but it works very well on my skin. Indeed, I get equal performance to Colonia Oud (that unlike other reviewers, is not a beast on my skin): that is a moderate/good projection in the first hour, and then a moderate to low projection in the following 3 to 4 hours, before settling as a skin scent.
Like for Colonia Oud, I can still spot Colonia Ambra as a subtle skin scent after 12+ hours.

My preference goes to Ambra compared to the Oud, since I think Oud's opening is less interesting. That said, you really have to like ambregris, since Ambra is more linear than Oud (the latter evolves more with time, and the drydown is warmer and more luxurious than the opening).
Should you look for something to wear during Fall and Spring days (and possibly Summer evenings) that is more unique and fresh, go for Ambra. Should you like for something to wear during Winter days and Fall/Spring evenings, that is more woody, warm and formal, go for Oud.

My preference goes to Colonia Ambra, because of its higher wow factor, and because the Colonia Oud opening is more common (usual designer oud frag "wet woody note" - no real oud in this one).
In either case, you can't go wrong, just a matter of preference.

Note: ignore the reviews stating that it smells synthetic or has poor performance because:
A/ each skin react differently
B/ each nose perceives things differently
C/ statement like "it's synthetic" makes a sense only for someone who has directly got his nose over a vial of real ambergris tincture (probably very few - if any here).

Sample and judge by yourself! (AdP is pretty mainstream now and can be found easily in many dept stores)

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: animalic ambergris, monotonous. goes from dark grey to silver light. great at drydown.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I concur 100% with the user "desordenado" -- "old paintings" was the first impression I got from Colonia Ambra as well. It is old, musky, piercing, pungent and strangely alluring at the same time. Definitely animalic, more like fur than cured leather, with a sparkling tingle on top. As it sometimes happens, the first sniff entailed a resolute no-no, but then the curiosity got the better of me and I found myself returning to this olfactory goodness. What I especially like about it, is the relative lack of sweetness. On one hand, it means that we are not dealing with a crowdpleaser here, far from it. Do not blind buy this fragrance. On the other hand, it adds to the originality of the scent and lets you enjoy the specific salty-sweet ambergris muskiness without the plethora of additional notes that are usually put in the more crowdpleasing aquatics. I mean, this thing is raw! At the same time, I get an impression that you'd have to dress up for Colonia Ambra to acquire a certain gravitas and balance the primal instincts that this fragrance could elicit.

BTW, reading some of the reviews, I'm surprised that the animalic ambergris note (synthetic or not) is being constantly mixed up with the oriental amber note. It's not Colonia Ambra's fault that it can't size up to some of the greatest *amber* fragrances. You're comparing apples with oranges.

***

After a full wearing, I have to update my review. Unfortunately, this didn't work well on my skin+clothes. I didn't get the sexy animalics vibe nor freshness, more like a stale pungent odour. Had to wash it off. Sorry. Goes to show that you have to thoroughly test fragrances in real life to appreciate the real effect, not just the aesthetic of the notes. It really matters, whether you spray it on the wrist, chest, clothes, hair or blotter. I tested it on my forearm, but wore it on my chest area and it smelled like whole different thing. Of course, ideally you would wear it a few years and then post a review, but that's a bit unrealistic.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Typically 90s.
Start fresh, sweet, watery with citrus, violet leaf, roses,woods and generic musk.
It gets worse on the bottom when the skin warms up and
to my nose remains mature,flat and overly synthetic.I really think I hate ambroxan.
Perhaps the most annoying of this house.
Great during the day, for the gym or outdoor activities.
For skins that devour perfumes.
The price?? blasphemous.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I do not get where folks state it is Colonia Oud without the oud. The is a wonderful, simple fragrance that stands out on its own. Divine simplcity combined with subtleness of the the scent make this a masterpiece of elegance.

Alluring and sexy, capricious and sublime....that is what this fragrance is. No earthiness whatsover. Gorgeous from the get go and the dry down is great.

I would imagine this is what elves out of Tolkien would smell like.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: This fragrance smell so good it's a shame projection and sillage are under the average range. That said, If you like aquatic fragrances and if performances like those of Millesime Imperial by Creed or l'humaniste by Frapin are not an issue for you, you should try this. It's a beautiful, easy wearable, non offensive casual scent that you can easily rock to the gym or to the office because longevity is fine.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: i really smell oud in there

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
An interesting fragrance. I love it. Ambra definitely grew on me.

Upon first spraying and testing, I couldn't get the idea of some fancy, vintage wooden furniture out of my head. It smelled too linear, sharp and musky. I gave it another shot a few days later, and ever since, I've been loving Colonia Ambra.

Colonia Ambra starts very sharp, with citrusy and aquatic-type notes. Very quickly, sandalwood and patchouli peek through. The result is a thick, sharp, dense cloud of Italian refinement. Soon after, the ambergris (or ambroxan) can be detected. Subtle, but present. In my opinion, this is what makes this fragrance have excellent longevity on my skin. There is a hint of the Creed DNA here very late in the dry-down; Sandalwood and Ambergris are the likely culprits.

Main notes to my nose are: citrus, sandalwood, patchouli and ambergris.

This ends up smelling very rugged yet somehow smooth, and those around me seem to love it.

Longevity is at around 12 hours, projecting for 4 hours.

Chic and sharp.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Trying this today, and have to say that it is a very beautiful fragrance. To be fair I'm a big Ambroxan fan! There are also hints of rose and oud. However, the longevity and silage are poor - if this was a big powerhouse frag I'd be buying a bottle.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: I love this stuff, but it's staying power is so weak, it's not worth buying...it's a shame as it's so beautiful

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: AMAZING! Can't stop wearing it honestly

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
rating: 6.5/10
I read so many reviews about this perfume and I decided to give it a go buying online since it's not available in where I am located. I really like the smell but unfortunately it's a big disappointment for me that it lasts only 2 hours on me and all my friends said that they could not smell any fragrance on me at all. It is weak on me no matter in longevity and sillage.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
After trying out Oud, Leather and Ambra (I owned FBs of both Leather and Ambra) I have to say that only Leather is worth mentioning and is pretty good. Oud is no oud at all, it is a bland norlimbanol bomb and Ambra, whose having I regretted deeply as I bought it blind, as I thought that after Leather it should be a great Amber based fragrance. Sadly, Ambra was also very, very bad, a norlimbanol and ambroxan bomb with no character at all, smelling very synthetic.

I am very dissapointed in this house and will not buy from it again. They have exceptional design of the bottles and packaging, the story is great, but the substance is lacking. If anyone from AdP bothers to read these comments - focus more on substance, because this way you are not going to finish well. It seems to me that they are not even using ingredients that should be there, I certainly did not detect most of the notes that are listed, and in Ambra I am very sure there is no ambergris (I know that it is extremely rare that any perfume has it, however, if you compare exceptional ambers like TF AA or Profumum Ambra Aurea, this is far on the other side of the scale, pretty worthless). And for the price they are charging, it is a "emperor is naked" story.

As I see that AdP as a house does not use famous noses to make their scents, it also says a thing in itself. It looks like their marketing team is involved to create bland, lifeless fragrances that should appeal to rich snobs who are looking for something a bit better and with a bit more character than your usual designer fragrances.

Moving to the scent itself, it is barely appealing at some moments, very generic, and the strong synthetic notes persist 99% of the time of the duration of the scent.

For that reason I cannot give it more than

2/10

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Ambra forms another fragrance more in line Acqua di Parma: Ingredient Collection.

The opening does not feel fresh, from the beginning a musky character faceted woody reminding me very much to his sister Oud but without the leather and the soap base note here made it smoother better match the final result is printed.
The centerpiece of Ambra basically is the chord of ambergris combined with wood and rock rose, which produces facets animals, dry and slightly salty, but never smell the sea.

However, it still seems somewhat synthetic and artificial by the note of ambergris (Ambroxan) so obvious, undisguised and simple.

Still, the resulting aroma is original, wearable and it's nice. The duration is very good and well planned.

an ode to Ambroxan.

Rating: 5

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
No sea fragrance at all! Ambergris! Soft, warm, golden, a little rough.
It smells like antiques, no smell of old and dust, it smells like the museum, which displays paintings of the Italian Renaissance.
Definitely it`s a smell for me. I got it right after first trying. Surprise speeches about "who can wear this?"
Slightly stricter and colder than Oud AdP. And definitely finer and thinner.
From a series of Blu Mediterraneo unfortunately I was not thrilled.

***
Still here musk lurks on closer examination. Most likely this is it gives light chillness which at times from skin condition is able to transform into the smell of sweaty beast.
As a result: a warm, velvety, amber fragrance with age, highbrow, musk coolth of the Zoological Museum.

Pyramid, as usual for new flavors, contains not all components:

Top: Orange, Bergamot, Petitgrain, Rose
Heart: nagarmotha (cypriol, nut grass), wood of Virginia cedar, patchouli, ambergris
Base: wood sandalwood, cistus, musk

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Molto intenso e persistente, dominato da muschio bianco e ambra grigia. Un po' penetrante e un filo sintetico. Buono, ma il prezzo è sproporzionato.

Voto personale: 8/10

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Unfortunately another strike for me as far as this brand is concerned.
Straight up synthetic hairspray smell as far as I'm concerned.Cannot detect any amber,vanilla or anything in the slightest bit perfume like.Nothing smooth here,very high pitched and screechy.
This is definitely no amber relation to TF Amber Absolute or Lutens Ambre Sultan.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: OK. Let's say I just came from Rome, and I love shoping in Acqua di Parma boutique in Rome, and have already bought many of their perfumes. So this time I bought the Ambra. It is really perfect, but....it lasts only half an hour. I was so dissapointed, because I paid 172 euros for 100 ml. Instead I should have gone back to Oud, as they belong to the same line, but the oud lasts much longer. I don't like such an expensive fragnance ending in my wardrobe at work.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
An Italian art! How amazing!
This is an Eau de Cologne concentrate, so we cannot really talking about it as a heavy hitter, it is a skin smell without any beast mode sillage, but smells phenomenal.
About 6-7 hours pure high quality gently ambergris journey with orange oil at the beginning, just a hint of cedar and rosewood notes in the middle and vanilla at the end.
Super sophisticated fragrance with the classical AdP presentation. Luxury smells for men!
I just adore it!!!

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Incredible;-)

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Lots of musk paired with real ambergis.

The musk is so sweet that it imitates flowery notes.

Too sweet for my likings but very nice and attractive.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
It's 2015
I love Acqua di Parma fragrance.they are gorgeous!
Colonia Ambra is very good with great longevity and silage..it is My favorite perfume
It's near to oud colonia but different, A powerful masculine fragrance..excellent .masterpiece
interesting smell..great stuff.. It's a fantastic
one of my most complimented fragrances when I wear it

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells like the oud version without the oud. Loud and piercing citrus fresh. There a note in here that stings the nose and is uncomfortable to wear.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Absolutely dreamlike for men. At first, I could only smell the rose and was concerned about not enjoying it because of that, but the rose aspect tends to vanish a little and there remains an incredible woody scent that I can't help but sniff on my wrist. It is veey expensive so not for me now, but it overclasses most other masculine perfumes for my tastes.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The whole page for this is messed up!! Taken from an official tester bottle

Group: Woody Aromatic

Top Notes: Orange, bergamot, petit grain
Heart Notes: Rose accord, cypriol, virginia cedarwood, patchouli
Base Notes: Ambergris, sandalwood, cisto labdanum, vanilla, musk

There are no oceanic notes!!! I guess this is the power of persuasion. If someone tells you this cologne contains marine notes, perhaps 8-9/10 will smell them! I get no such smell. Instead I get a rich citrus up top (i.e. not sparkling) that is more clean then fresh. Next I get a warm earthy middle of patchouli and velvety rose. Then the ambergris starts to kick in. This is not the Creed ambergris, this one is much more earthy. I get mostly darker sandalwood, ambergris, and musk out of this to create an overall effect of earthy wood.

I get similarities between this and ADP oud. As with the rest of the line, the quality is noticeable and the perfume lays rich and thick on the skin giving of a sophisticated aura. Not super heavy projection but definite sillage and longevity! I will revisit this one for sure!

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The original Acqua di Parma 'Colonia' fragrance featured sparkling citrus notes in the top married with an aromatic herbal accord of lavender, rosemary, and lemon verbena. Floral heart notes of rose and jasmine intermingled with warm sandalwood, patchouli, vetiver and amber in the base. The result was a classic and timeless fragrance which embodied the elegance of the Aqcua di Parma brand. Using the original citrus based 'Colonia' as a launching point, 'Colonia Ambra' takes us on a journey to the warm and musky air of coastal beaches. Here 'Colonia' and the Italian tradition are blended with the deep sensuality of ambergris, an ancient essence evocative of faraway worlds and times. The opening citrus is still present, with zesty orange and bergamot full of life. A heart of cedar wood, rose and patchouli follows, melding gently with the hesperidic top notes. The real centerpiece of this creation is the warm and enveloping base notes as rich ambergris, sandalwood and vanilla combine. Upon application, the wearer is cocooned in a sensual amber and marine accord. It is extremely comforting and exhilarating to wear, yet at the same time sophisticated and well-refined. Next to 'Colonia Oud', it is my favorite within the "Ingredient Collection" trilogy ('Colonia Leather' did little for me).

Read my complete review at my personal fragrance blog:

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Sampled this beauty in Rome earlier this summer and it is terrific. Simply put- the scent of a well dressed professional! 10/10

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is a warm, hearty amber fragrance that expresses the main note well with a heavy dose of vanilla. I don't detect any of the citrus notes opening notes, as I didn't find that this opened with more acidity or brightness than the rest of its life--it was nicely consistent. Ambergris may be present.

At the higher price of the oud/amber/leather group, greater projection is expected, and Colonia Ambra delivers somewhat, though this is no powerhouse (in fairness, it's still described as a EDC but in my estimation, ADP uses EDC liberally).

This is too new for the fragrancenet market so it's still only available at its retail price, which isn't bad. Fans of amber and vanilla should explore this, but at the current price ($220 for 100ml), I'm not sure with its longevity and projection, which are decent but not great, it's a worthwhile purchase.

7 out of 10

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I already own several bottles of Acqua di Parma, I was interested in trying Ambra. I just bought a bottle and this stuff is really different from the others. When I sprayed this juice on my skin the notes were dancing. Besides Ambergris this juice gives a deep honey/patchouli vib ending with a hint of smokey/woodsy base. Water notes are listed but I'm not able to pick it up. The musk notes certainty gives it warm tone.
Longevity and Silage is excellent lasting 6-8hrs if I spray it 2x. I'm able to detect the aroma at least 1ft away after it's settled.
Final thoughts,
Kudos to ADP, this juice is a real attractive fragrance they used high quality ambergris. A lot Purfumery's add either vanilla or oakmoss to give it that warm/woodsy aroma. ADP didn't overlap different notes which would of decreased the intensity of Ambergrism The only thing that I'm disappointed with is that I didn't buy the large bottle. Try it for yourself and let the fragrance settle before you give it two thumbs up or down. This is DEFINITELY worth two thumbs up in my opinion. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Very nice! It has some similarities with Colonia Oud, but this one is more mild and "pretty". Fresh notes on a sweet ambergris/musk base with hints of soft creamy vanilla. It's totaly irrestistible! Quite uncommon as a Colonia scent, this is an oriental fragrance. This is the most unisex of the Concentree line, and can easily be worn by women too. First Oud, then Leather, and now this! Where will it end? I'm very impressed!

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Yes, VERY much like Intensa Oud. Not an exact copy... but the aromachemical AdP used here to simulate ambergris must have a very similar structure to the one used for their Intensa Oud.

I have Colonia/Intensa Oud. And I wouldn't buy Ambra until I run out of the Oud. And I probably will. I do like that slightly fresher accord perhaps from the musk and "marine notes" (whatever they are supposed to represent!). But tastes can drift over time... both are great.

With either Ambra or Oud, you should test before you buy. In fact, I recommend getting both to sample and live with them for a while.

Btw, Ambra longevity is excellent! I think it may be a little better than Intensa Oud.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: A fresher, more wearable version of Acqua di Parma's Oud. Don't trust the name.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Tried it today, I like it but there are strong similarities to the Oud. Although I the Ambergris is more pronounced. I wonder, is there Ambergris in the Acqua di Parma Oud? If so, its not listed in the notes...

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Okay stays over 12 hours on my skin then another 6 to 8 skin scent. Its a winner in my book also I've heard it close to oud trust me its different than leather or oud.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
I hope people do not mistake 'ambra' for amber. It isn't amber, but its ambergris.
There is no amber in its note breakdown.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smelled this today: I was surprised, I am not super well versed but I can say that it was an amber with a fresh top, bergamot? and definitely featured a surprising hint of patchouli in the amber-y base. Didn't try it on my skin so I am not really capable of making longevity or sillage comments but I am a terrible person to test longevity on anyway. It was interesting and it certainly smelled good. I'll have to have a deeper test before I think about buying though.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Came from barneys of ny today pre ordered. 4 sprays let see how long it last on my skin. Can tell you now it a keeper for me. Has a very sexy musk smell and not to loud.

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The fragrance hasn't even been released and yet there are 4 votes for longevity and 3 for sillage.

Just stop it!!!!

product_name: Colonia Ambra Acqua di Parma
review_content: Wow!!! This put a huge smile on my face. Can't wait.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Sampling now, great citrus flash at the opening, but the middle is way too floral for me. Just looked at the middle notes listed above — no wonder why it’s so floral (roses and lily!).

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Extremely underrated fragrance. You can easily find this for 65-75 USD per 100ml. Opens with typical high quality ADP citruses and a beautiful neroli soap. The soap stays around throughout, if you’ve ever smelled a florentine soap bar or those expensive bars of soap you can find all over Tuscany, that’s the soap you get here. It’s in a category that I would consider “Italian fougere,” soapy and citrus forward instead of lavender/patchouli. There is a traditional vibe to this but without smelling dated, way more modern imo than Colonia or Intensa. There’s a bit of herbal/green facet here but nothing that sticks out and it’s blended very well. Anyone that likes soapy frags should definitely try this. It’s a decent performer but with how natural it smells I wouldn’t expect it to last long anyways. This is not a fragrance you wear to turn necks, it’s there to make you smell like a clean man who knows what he wants and knows where he is going. it will project moderately for the first couple hours. for anyone that gets intimately close to you, it will smell like you just got out of the shower for 6+ hours after application. Perfect for summer and spring. It’s an unbelievable value at discounters. I think ADP is one of the most overlooked houses. Natural, masterfully blended fragrances from a house that represents the smells of Italy better than anyone else and has a variety of fresh scents. Everyone can find one they really like.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Job interview. You got the job

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This one is really nice. It’s classy, mature fresh scent. To my knows, it almost smells like a lemon hard candy. There’s also a powdery element to this. It gives it a somewhat barbershoppy scent.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
You spritz Colonia Essenza and in that first moment you’re standing on a sunlit piazza in Italy, early morning light glowing off cobblestones. There’s a burst of citrus—lemon, bergamot, orange—so bright and clean it feels like fresh dew. The sweetness isn’t in your face; it’s refined, luminous, as though the light itself has a scent.

As the fragrance warms, it reveals a heart of white blossoms and Italian herbs: neroli, jasmine, lily-of-the-valley, and a whisper of rosemary and clove. It’s floral but never fussy—graceful, elegant, with character. The herbs give it a gentle backbone, so it’s not just light and easy; there’s depth alongside the radiance.

In the dry-down, soft clean woods, musk, and amber take over. Think fresh linen, polished leather, and a gentle after-shave touch. The skin scent lingers—clean, comforting, sophisticated. It doesn’t try to shout; it wins through subtlety. You feel polished and quietly confident.

Longevity is above average, around 8-10 hours on my skin with moderate sillage.

Highly Recommended 9/10.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Very identical to Lorenzo Villoresi Acqua Di Colonia (1996) on the opening.
However, Eccenza feels a bit more perfumy polished, a slight denser and has this soapier depth to it. Plus, it has the light sweet fruity drydown. I believe it could be because of the lily of the valley that adds this soapiness.
Eccenza lasts longer of course and the soapiness is comforting. Eccenza is also a nod to its own house pioneer, Colonia.

But if you like this type of scent in the most natural way possible without the sweetness or touch of soapiness. Lorenzo Villoresi’s Acqua Di Colonia is the winner. It is green and fresh with edges. It feels natural and organic compared to Essenza. But the freshness fades away eventually without any clear drydown for a goodbye.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Just beautiful. Like colonia but the fizzy citrus of the opening is dialled down and the neroli and petitgrain dialled up. I find it great in high heat where it gives a masculine clean soapy vibe with a bit of earthiness to boot. There’s enough body to it to work all year round for me too. Understated sophistication.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Today, I'm reaching for the very last Acqua di Parma fragrance in my current collection: Essenza di Colonia. My journey through this particular line has been quite a study, starting with the classic original Colonia, then moving to the updated Colonia Futura. Both, regrettably, left me underwhelmed by their performance, though the original Colonia certainly possessed a more appealing scent profile than Futura, which struck me as somewhat dissonant. I'm approaching Essenza with an open mind, unsure of what awaits, but truly hoping it holds something special, allowing me to conclude my Acqua di Parma exploration on a positive note. Let's get into it.


Opening:
The opening is a luminous display of vibrant florals, sparkling citrus, and fresh aromatics. The primary notes that immediately captivate me are neroli, jasmine, bergamot, and orange. Neroli and bergamot lead the initial symphony. The neroli immediately takes the spotlight with a generous dose of radiant white florals, gracefully underscored by a subtle citrusy nuance. This particular neroli note bears a striking resemblance to the one prominently featured in Tom Ford's Neroli Portofino. Following closely behind, the bergamot contributes a familiar citrus accord, accompanied by its characteristic aromatic and subtly spicy tones. Next, jasmine and orange weave into the composition. The jasmine adds more white florals to the opening, yet it distinguishes itself from the neroli through its inherent sweetness. Lastly, the orange provides a touch more citrus in the background, emphasizing its sweet and juicy facets.


Dry Down:
The dry down gently evolves, maintaining its core as a blend of luminous florals, soft citrus, and comforting freshness. The primary notes I continue to discern are neroli, jasmine, musk, and bergamot. Neroli and jasmine remain the strongest presences. The neroli continues to be a highlight in the dry down, carrying the same white floral and subtle citrusy accord, albeit more quietly than in the opening. Meanwhile, the jasmine has grown in strength, delivering that same sweet, white floral punch from its initial appearance. However, it has now developed a distinctly creamy, almost "suntan lotion" solar accord, adding an interesting depth. This evolving heart is then joined by musk and bergamot. The bergamot is still present in the dry down with its familiar citrusy and subtly spicy accord, but it has gracefully receded to the background. Lastly, the musk emerges, lending the dry down a soft and fuzzy freshness in the base, completing the clean and inviting aura.


Performance:
The initial projection is commendable, reaching a respectable six feet. Sillage mirrors this energy, leaving an easily discernible scent trail. After a few hours, the projection had softened considerably, settling to about three feet, and the scent trail became lighter, though still noticeable. By the five to six-hour mark, the fragrance had transitioned to a skin scent, indicating a total discernible longevity of approximately four hours.


When to Wear:
Essenza di Colonia is unmistakably a spring and summer fragrance, ideally suited for daytime wear. The harmonious blend of florals and freshness gives it a bright, easygoing vibe, making it an excellent choice for casual outings or any outdoor scenario. However, its luminous and floral-heavy character suggests it wouldn't be my first pick for formal occasions or typical office wear.


Blind Buy:
If you find yourself drawn to fragrances with a prominent neroli signature, particularly if you enjoy the style of Neroli Portofino, this would most likely be a safe blind buy for your collection.


Final Verdict:
Essenza di Colonia, to my nose, is Acqua di Parma's refined interpretation of the Neroli Portofino DNA. There is certainly nothing inherently wrong with that; Neroli Portofino is, after all, a very popular creation from Tom Ford. However, it also happens to be one of my personal least favorite Tom Ford fragrances I've ever experienced. With that being said, Essenza did not truly resonate with me. I will concede that I find it marginally more appealing than Neroli Portofino, but still not enough to wholeheartedly declare that I "like it." Unfortunately, Essenza did little to alleviate the persistent performance issues that have characterized my experience with the Colonia line. While it started strong, which is more than I can say for the others I've tried, it faded quickly, becoming a skin scent by the five to six-hour mark. Having now concluded my extensive journey with Acqua di Parma, I believe I can confidently state that this house, as a whole, is simply not for me. While some of their fragrances do possess pleasant scent profiles, the recurring lack of robust performance across virtually every fragrance I tried, coupled with their premium price point, ultimately creates a value proposition that doesn't quite translate for my preferences. Still, as they say, you never truly know until you try.


Scent: 6/10
Longevity: 6/10
Sillage: 6/10
Versatility: Below average
Mass Appeal: Average
Gender: Unisex
Value: Way overpriced

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Such a gorgeous, gorgeous scent. From the beginning uplifting and vibrant feeling. To my nose it has the dirty citrus of aramis tuscany vintage version and the bright freshness of armani eau pour home. Solid longevity as well. A keeper for me

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
To my surprise and disappointment — a barbershop scent. The kind that’s a slight step up from Drakkar, like Paco Rabanne, though not quite Azzaro. Maybe a bit like Pasha.

Suddenly it turns out to be more oriental than I initially thought. It starts moving toward notes like Chanel Pour Monsieur or Rive Gauche. Will it drop the lavender? The oriental part here is heavy — maybe even more enveloping than in the Chanel.

To me, though, it feels like a kind of Chanel knockoff. My opinion drops accordingly. The lavender fades away completely, and what remains is a narrow corridor of sweetness in the Chanel style — but weaker.

⸻

A lot of time has passed, and I can now take this scent more seriously. My citrus–fougère journey has left behind all the Portofinos, Amalfis, Soles di Positanos, and YSL Pour Homme fragrances.

Honestly, I haven’t found a citrus scent that truly suits me — they’re either fleeting breezes or old-man trash. Acqua Viva becomes too warm, Eau de Yuzu and Lemon Line are too candy-like, Oranges & Lemons or Melone Grapefruit disappear after 8 minutes, and Dior Cologne is too linear (though I’m not done with it yet).

I also can’t get into any mint scents — not You Or Someone Like You, not Minthe by Diptyque, not Beach Hut or Enclave, nor any of the others, which mostly stay linear and merely naturalistic.

My only saving grace so far is Aventus — but that can’t be it. I want something more natural, fresher, more connected to nature. That’s why I’m thinking about Essenza — it’s refreshing, citrusy, but maintains the right amount of fougère character, which gives it distinction.

It’s genuinely good, without being as old-man-ish as YSL PH.

Before buying it, though, I should still have a conversation with the last big contender (to be rejected), Fathom V, and the new player, Lippizan.

Essenza has a certain type of unpretentious elegance — like something you’d wear during an intermission at a vernissage on a sun-scorched Mediterranean coast, when people have stepped outside just to breathe for a moment.

There’s no real depth here — it’s only hinted at. But that sketch is filled in by life.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Classic neroli and jasmine but very masculine. One of the best and underrated colognes that’s versatile and strong enough for all seasons.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is what got me into fragrances properly, something totally different to what is usually accessible commercially and I wanted it as soon as I first smelled it. I know these notes are typically seen as a bit old fashioned but to someone who is new to the game its a really nice uplifting smell that is really addictive. I get really bad performance out of this though, like 2 hours until it becomes a skin scent on me. I spray like 10-12 and it still seems to disappear. But this helped me realize the notes I really care about and there is something in there for everyone which makes it pretty universal despite smelling so particular. That being said this is like the opposite of a blue-aquatic, sporty, modern fragrance. If your a fan of synthetic/modern scents like ysl you will probably hate this. The dry down does eventually go a bit grassy on my skin as well which is probably the vetiver but not unpleasant.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Blind bought this one and the original Colonia since I like these profiles. They both feel a bit old school but very nice

I think Essenza smells pretty similar to Kourous (dont think ive seen anyone mention it), but a bit toned down and more crowd pleasing

And the original Colonia smells a lot Eau Sauvage as many people have said in here

Both really good dumb reaches for everyday wear

Edit; Regarding performance on the Essenza, Its pretty bad it is what I like to call a "sleeper", like it sits on the skin and pumps up if your body temp goes up. I like those kind of perfumes. Eau Sauvage is the same for me

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Essenza (2010) – Acqua di Parma.
The Olfactory Family of Citrus Woody Men, created in 2010.
Colonia Essenza, from the prestigious Italian house Acqua di Parma, is a men's fragrance that exudes classic sophistication with a modern touch. With an eau de cologne concentration, it brings a fresh and refined signature, ideal for men who value timeless elegance.

The opening is a vibrant citrus explosion with lemon, orange, bergamot and grapefruit, providing an invigorating and luminous start. Then, aromatic and floral touches emerge with neroli, jasmine, lemon leaf and rosemary, composing a heart balanced between freshness and sophistication. The base is drier and woodier, with vetiver, patchouli, amber and white musk, ensuring a solid fixation and a clean and subtly seductive trail.

Perfect for daytime use, especially in work environments, daytime social events, casual encounters and situations where you want to be elegant without going overboard. Ideal for warmer climates, such as spring and summer, but versatile enough to be used all year round.

Performance: Moderate projection and longevity of around 7 hours, with respectable performance for an eau de cologne. The fragrance evolves in a refined and natural way on the skin, without being aggressive.

Bottle: The black and white design conveys an image of minimalist and timeless luxury, accurately reflecting the perfume's proposal.

Final Score: 9/10

A versatile, luxurious and extremely well-constructed fragrance, highlighting the naturalness of the ingredients. For lovers of the modern barbershop style or for those looking for a citrus perfume with lasting elegance, Colonia Essenza is a sure choice.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is the Portofino coast in a bottle. Literally too, based off where this brand comes from. Picture this: you’re wearing a light blue and white plaid button up with linen pants walking across the boardwalk on the Portofino coast, getting wafts of the neroli plants nearby and breezy air that smells like the height of summer. There’s also a bar next to you, they juice all kinds of citruses, and the rinds of orange, lemon, and grapefruit mix up in the air as well. So refreshing and the epitome of summer. It smells like entering the presence of the beach or the pool.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Like a bomb of bitter white flowers and soap hit your face. This seems to be a strong projecting fresh fragrance, also strong in odor. You're hit with it as soon as you spray it on a tester strip, no need to get your nose too close to it. I'd say it's a bit mature, but the smell intrigued me. Classic, soapy, sharp but not annoyingly so.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is fantastic Soapy Scent, very Fresh and works well in Hot Summer as well as Spring. Bit cloying if wore during night time. Avoid it. Wear it in Outdoors.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Fancy italian soap :)) where? Behave yourselves, it's an old fashioned barber fragrance, you get some bad vetiver, néroli, yuzu, some citrus notes; very weak, nothing stands out, scent profile is outdated to say the least, price is outrageous, go search your grandads aftershave and save money, do not buy it.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This one smells sharp and fresh.

Right away, you get lemon, orange, and bergamot all blended smoothly. Then it settles into a barbershop vibe with neroli, some florals, and a touch of woods and musk. It feels upscale without trying too hard.

Longevity is decent for a citrus scent — it won’t last all day, but it sticks around long enough to get noticed. You can definitely wear it daily if you want that fresh, polished vibe.

If you like classic masculine scents with a fresh twist, this one’s worth checking out.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells like Irish Spring. Way too soapy for me

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Stunning! Best fragrance for summer i tried this far. Seems to last about 4 hours.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: If you don't care for vetiver with soap, you might not enjoy this one. Disappointed in this one and a risky blind buy.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Essenza is a cool, very fragrant summer fragrance and a true gentleman's fragrance based on the scent of Neroli with spicy and bitter citrus notes, partially balanced with white musk and jasmine.
The overall scent has a strong soapy feel that may not appeal to some who are wary of certain scents at first, but if worn in the right situation and style, it is truly amazing. The performance is very good for a cool scent and if you connect with this scent, its values will prove to you.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Really nice and fresh, a little bit old school. Reminiscent of Eau Sauvage and Neroli Portofino. Perfect Italian summer vacation fragrance.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Even though we can find Mendeleev’s periodic table here, I like it.
But why does it remind me of … EDP Colonia IL PROFUMO…2025 ?

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: The opening starts of great. Citrus with hints of floral. After about 2 hours it starts to go down to about a C tier unfortunately due to the loss of citrus and the take over of neroli and jasmine. From there it slowly fades off leaving you wondering what happened to your summer fragrance you put on a few hours ago.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: it's a classy and mature citrus scent. not quite my thing but I gave it to my father and he loves it. the fragrance performs very well, great projection off of just a couple sprays

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Colonia Essenza is what you should smell like while lounging in the sun on the coasts of Italy, wearing a white button shirt, reading a book, and looking sophisticated.

The opening is a strong, straightforward citrus, made up of the highest-quality smelling, zesty lemon, grapefruit and orange. Instead of the bitterness from the pith of a real citrus, you get a fresh, clean note from the florals and musk. This opening combination is best described as invigorating and vibrant. After around an hour or so, the citruses settle, and you start to smell the aromatics and florals which give Essenza its calming soapy vibe - the expensive kind you'd find in hotels.

Acqua di Parma seems to be one of the most frequently discounted niche brands, making it cheaper than many of the popular designers, so if you're looking for that hot weather hit, maybe turn your attention away from those Le Beau's and Sauvage's and give Essenza a try.

Overall, I think its an excellent summer fragrance, and criminally overlooked. Performance is above average - I can imagine the citrusy freshness radiates all day during the hottest weather. I would pick this over Neroli Portofino ten times out of ten, considering how similar the DNA and quality is for a fraction of the price.

Smell: 8.5/10
Performance:7/10
Presentation: 7/10
Value: 8/10
Overall: 8/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Was not expecting this. The base comes off so strong. There is a very prominent backbone of rosemary, vetiver, patchouli, oak moss, and musk. I didn’t look at the notes before I tried this and I just hit em with “woahhh this has oak moss”. It smells strongly of neroli as well, and it’s fluffy but you just gotta keep in mind that the backbone of this is that grandpa aftershave type shit. Fire though

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Essenza di Colonia opens with a vibrant explosion of Italian citrus. Neroli, from the white blossom of the bitter orange tree, forms the heart of the fragrance from the outset.

The dry-down is clean and mature, with neroli starring alongside a supporting cast of florals and rosemary. It evokes memories of barbershop shaves, with both the sharpness of the razor and the powdery softness of the soap.

Unfortunately, the same soapy cleanness that distinguishes this fragrance also holds it back. Essenza di Colonia is classic and gentlemanly, but antiquated. It is a barbershop scent ill-suited for the outside world — the kind of thing you would smell on an old Italian man at church. It feels alien on my young skin.

6/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: One of Albertos finest creations. For a 15 years young scent it's stood the test of time. Elegant and a reference for a gentleman's cologne. The brief here was exceeded

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: It’s fancy soap. Very very fancy soap. Luxuriously fancy soap for a classy fancy gent. Worth every penny!

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
A calming, uplifting, neroli forward citrus, great to wear on rotation. It has a classical Italian cologne vibe & it's extremely refreshing. Pure joy.

IG : @scentclouds
YouTube : @scentclouds

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Wow, the citrus on the opening really unique, smooth, like Citrus squash.. not your typical citrus, its bold and have a depth but still maintain freshness..

The opening is so good, after dry down its lighter, can use it daily, cant go wrong

Overall score : 8.3

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Still on the hunt for a second Acqua di Parma fragrance to rival my beloved Fico di Amalfi, this week I’ve been testing Colonia Essenza. When testing a scent, I find many that open with harsh citrus notes, but that's definitely not the case here. Essenza has one of the most perfect openings I’ve ever experienced. To my nose, it is remarkably similar to Dior’s Eau Sauvage EdT, which is a long-time favourite of mine. In fact, in terms of its openning, Essenza is like an amplified version of all that makes Eau Sauvage great.

Opening with citrus notes of grapefruit, bergamot, and orange, Essenza fizzes and sparkles as it first hits the nose. After about ten minutes, notes of neroli, petitgrain, and rosemary emerge, and the scent becomes noticeably more bitter as the juicy citrus notes fade. It’s not unpleasant to me, but sadly it doesn’t fulfill the promise of the opening. At this point, Essenza diverges quite significantly from Eau Sauvage. It continues evolving rapidly, and it isn’t long before the bitterness gives way to musk and the warm, spicy tones of sage and clove, which take centre stage for a while. Vetiver lurks in the background, subtle for the moment.

By the hour mark, Essenza has settled. The spicy notes from earlier are now less stark, and the vetiver becomes more prominent. I also begin to detect hints of rose and amber, resulting in a warm, mellow, and slightly powdery experience.

There’s much I like about Essenza, but I also have a major reservation. Beyond the first few minutes of its development, there’s an underlying note that presents as sour to my nose. I’m sensitive to ambroxan, and I wonder if that’s what I’m picking up here. Unfortunately, ambroxan has ruined several otherwise excellent fragrances for me. However, unlike with those others, the note in Essenza is more elusive; sometimes it is barely perceptible and sometimes it is not evident at all. Taking everything into account, I’m left in a quandary when it comes to Essenza.

Tested: 1ml decant.
Seasons / Occasions: Warm weather. All occasions.
Key thoughts: Nice in many respects, but I sometimes detect something sour in the background that I dislike.
Overall rating: 7.5/10.
Buy full bottle: Undecided

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is brilliant, it smells so fresh and clean. It smells kind of airy, like you are in the mediterrenean, surrounded by pure nature, but there is water in the close distance that you can see. Bergamont and neroli are the main notes, smells classy too. It is extremely well blended together, super smooth. Although this is described as a summer scent, I believe you can pull it off all year around, because of the very simple smell, it smells like just cologne water (it is) but just clean and refreshing, thats why in the winter I think if you go light on the sprays, its just your smell, or a smell. Though very simple its really well put together, lasts a long time for me, I easily get 8+ hours on it, smooth, clean and elegant.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: A more refined Leau Dissey

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Straight to the point, Smells very elegant and high quality but its relatively simple, it changes a bit during the drydown but still remains simple, you understand that its been made out of decent quality ingredients but it smells like a pine tree soap with citrus, its not bad the opposite but its simple, many say that it has some depth but i dont see it. It projects the first 2 hours after that it becomes a skin scent for like 5 more hours at least on my skin.
Conclusion: Very simple yet extremely elegant perfume if you want to be called 'SIR' and smell rich this is the perfume for you but the performance is poor.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: I love this soapy neroli bliss. Clean and fresh for hours to come. I love how the musk and amber pulls it all together. For me this is a 50/50 white/green scent. Perfection for a warm spring day.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This one is unwearable for me, sadly.

There's a soapy-green accord in this that seriously makes me nauseous. It smells fine from a distance, on fabric or whatever, but on my skin it's a no-go. Totally different experience on skin.

Be sure to test this one before buying.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is (I think) definitely a Francois Demachy creation. Some resemblance with Dior Eau Sauvage Extreme. Pure Italian citrus elegance in a black bottle. More masculine, sturdy, darker and longer lasting than the og Colonia.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Soapy, floral, citrus.
Everything is fine up until the far dry down where the aroma is like- a smooth-chalky bland candy (unsweetened).. I can’t help but to think of the colors & texture of Smarties candy.

Overall I prefer Alexandria’s The Irish Gentleman/ GIT

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Lots of talk in the reviews about this being a green vs. white scent. I'm on team white for this one. It's all citrus and white florals to me. Essenza pulls off those fresh, clean, citrusy, soapy, Italian gentleman vibes better than Neroli Portofino, and in a longer-lasting, more affordable package.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells like Heno de Pravia bathroom soap that was soaked in water. There's also a hint of a baby powder. But what I dislike is the after dry-down that smells similar to the air freshener in men's urinals.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This is my second review of Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza.

It's dry like a vodka martini with almost next to no sweetness in it. Essenza is a sharp, fresh, zesty, clean, green, soapy, citrusy, floral, and woodsy fragrance with a solid oakmoss foundation, which gives the fragrance extra heft and strength, and that oakmoss makes the fragrance lean more to the masculine side of the spectrum, although I don't see why a woman couldn't wear this one.

Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza is an intensely green, verdant, no-nonsense, straightforward, masculine, down-to-earth, old-fashioned, soapy, citrus cologne (cologne in name only; it probably has eau de toilette strength concentration), yet dignified, luxurious, aristocratic, and regal in nature.

You can dress it down with a pair of jeans or chinos and a crisp white t-shirt, and you can dress it up with a tuxedo and wear it with dignity, pride, and gravitas in more formal situations. That's how versatile Essenza is. It leans formal, but it can indeed be used in almost any setting: office, professional settings, vacations, and life's great festivities and celebratory moments.

Like very few fragrances out there, Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza manages the unique feat of transporting me out of the ordinary, dreary, humdrum daily life to the jet-set life of the rich, powerful, and famous in a glamorous setting.

Essenza is James Bond wearing a formal suit and tie in an Italian Mediterranean summer setting, surrounded by luxury and sports cars, casinos, 5-star hotels, old-fashioned Italian architecture, palm trees, clear blue skies, beautiful women, the glamorous luxury life, and the dark-blue colored Italian Mediterranean Sea in the background.

Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza is the good life, the easy life, the glamorous life, and the luxurious and privileged life. I'm at ease with myself and the world when I wear Essenza. There is nothing in the world to worry about.

I wrote earlier that Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza is green. It certainly is. Maybe not as green as, say, Creed Green Irish Tweed, but not far from it.

Essenza is as green as the Italian Mediterranean coast, but the fragrance also evokes images of the Scottish Highlands and the green rolling hills of Ireland, with a breath of fresh ocean air in the background.

The possible downsides, though, might be that its intensely soapy and floral character could be slightly overwhelming and off-putting for some people. Essenza might even smell like a washing detergent/laundry detergent, and the soapy, green, and oakmossy scent profile might torment the nostrils to a certain extent.

Essenza gets softer in the drydown, but it still remains an intensely sharp and soapy scent throughout its lifespan. Essenza also remains relatively simple, straightforward, and linear in its character, so it's not a complex or rich fragrance by any means.

For the right person, Acqua di Parma Colonia Essenza is signature scent worthy.

Final score: 7/10.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: I've been a fan of ADP since my 20's , role on to my 40's and with the original Colonia and Intensa being my absolute favourites never having lost my love of them but this no matter how hard I try since it's inception can I feel any thing positive. For me the lily of the valley is too prominent and nauseating. One thing that can be said of the bottles aesthetics though, it's mighty classy looking and ornamentally looks fantastic on the dresser.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: almost like a festive spring church soap and wet used towel. I love it. too artificial and unpleasant at first but settles in well. one of the best sopay citrus scent... i really love grapefruit and other citrus ingredients. works wonderfully with skin chemistry.... The scent is beautiful but only in the drydown

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells like a luxury soap. The neroli mixed with grapefruit gives it a sharp edge that bites pretty hard for the first 15 minutes. It doesn't smell like the typical white floral orange blossom or sunscreen if that is your concern. This frag lasted about 7 hour total on me, with the first 3 hrs being noticeable. As an Italian, I love this Italian fragrance

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Long lasting, but not nearly as gentle of a scent as OG Colonia, which I prefer by far.

It's okay, but I won't be wearing it again.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Simply put: High end Irish spring in cologne form. That might not be appealing to some, but I love it. Soapy, clean, green a bit old fashioned but not outdated, crazy projection especially first hour, good longevity for EDC (not weak by any means). Want to smell like a masculine guy that just got out the shower? This is your cologne. I can't say it enough: Irish spring.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This stuff makes even a shitty, foggy late winter day where the snow has melted into dirty gray slush feel like an all-expense-paid trip to Italy. The citrus in this is so bright and sparkly and fades into the composition nicely in the dry down to create this nice pure soapiness with a semi-modern aromatic fougere edge. It's an expensive soap that you steal from a hotel. It's definitely not modern by any standards, that old school Colonia DNA still carries this fragrance, but I wouldn't pin it as a dated fragrance that only the thirty and up crowd can rock. This DNA and style of perfume in general is so old that it carries a sort of untethered nostalgia, we know it's reminiscent of a different time but it isn't like grandpa's Polo Green or dad's Kouros that might be too familiar and old school for young people. Kind of gives off an old money vibe, which I think is something that is coming back into fashion. Also, for an eau de cologne, the performance on this is really good I get like 6 or 7 hours.

As for whether or not I recommend this, if you can get it for around like 70 or 80, it's worth it.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
very very very nice smelling fragrance, more mature, but I am young and like it a lot
performance is okay. I wouldnt buy a bottle, but decants to wear when I feel like it

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Really good mature citrus scent but unfortunately it only lasts like 3 hours on me. I'll have to keep wearing to give a solid review on this one though but for now it's about a 6/10 because it fades fast.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: A forever king on the throne. Will be a sad day when this gets discontinued. If heaven is real than I imagine this is the fragrance they use up there.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
10/10 masterpiece. Fresh, clean, classy and masculine. Not over the top or overly strong, sits close to the skin and allows your personality and charisma do all of the talking.
Smells like showering with a high quality soap, then putting on freshly washed clothes.
For me it lasts around 6 hours.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This scent lasts a lot longer than you might expect for a fresh citrus fragrance that is a Cologne style. I get at least a few hours of longevity. Opening is beautiful and it segs into a soapy feel as everyone has already mentioned. This is going to be the lily of the valley raw materials doing lots of work here whereas in something like suavage cologne you're getting mostly just the citrus and musk. So that one feels more natural than this but it's still a very good pickup. I bought a gift set recently which offset the price quite a bit so I was happy with that purchase, for some reason the gift set was cheaper than buying the individual bottle. But this is perfect for a professional setting and you can still smell the citruses even hours later. 5/5 for me. One day I was actually bored and I sprayed this one and compared it against three other cologne types, the suavage cologne, artisan pure, and this Eau Givenchy. All of those are EDT concentration but somehow this EDC outlasted them all.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: The scent lasts longer than expected

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: gorgeous and surprisingly complex, easily my favourite cologne style fragrance which says a lot. every time i sniff i discover something new. smells like an 65 year old Italian man watching the sunset after a bath

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: As with original colonia, i get up to 7-8 hours with this gem because i have oily skin. It's really good value for me. Quality you can smell.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: I love this stuff. It has a real old school Mediterranean gentleman vibe in a casual way and especially the opening is out of this world wonderful. The only thing is that I feel this one needs some proper heat to shine. I was gonna wear it as an office scent - and you can do that - but I feel the room temperature air-conditioned environment doesn´t do justice for this scent. I am saving mine for those hot summer days. Although it is November and I live way up North, so, yeah...

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
First of all, shout out to venusinyourfurs, who introduced this fragrance to little ol' me. She told me this would be a great scent if I like a niche fragrance with strong performance.

Initially, I thought Essenza would be a very citrus-based fragrance with a hint of floral notes, based on what everyone was saying. The opening was quite strong, which really caught me off guard. The first two sprays were really soapy and clean, but once everything settled down, it turned into a calming white floral scent. I didn't expect to like jasmine, neroli, and lily this much....very surprising!

Longevity 7.5/10
Projection 7.5/10
Scent 9/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: High end soap scent. Kinda linear. Tried a tester for a few days and I don't love it. Longevity is average.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: I sampled TF's neroli portofino a few months ago and although I thought the scent was decent it seemed overly mature. I consider Essenza di Colonia to smell very similar to NP and while still mature it's a lot more wearable for younger people. Seems like a lot of citruses were packed into the scent profile but the neroli is the most dominant to me, smelling clean and spicy. I would say it has an element that smells very similar to a generic green lollipop with it's sharp piercing and biting flavor at times. Like a lot of people have said, it definitely does smell like bar soap. I have definitely smelled soap like this at hotels, I'm guessing neroli-based soaps are popular among the hotel industry. I'm fortunately not getting too much rosemary, oakmoss or patchouli because those things can bring down a formulation in my opinion. I like that there is a bit of a dark aura to the scent, it's clean and fresh but also a bit sinister feeling too. Overall, I really do like Essenza, it's a much more wearable NP in my opinion but i'm not too sure if this can be properly worn outside of spring and summer. I would give Essenza di Colonia a 9/10, excellent for a neroli-based fragrance.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Acqua di Parma Essenza has a bold opening that feels intense but quickly settles into a clean, classic scent. Ideal for professional settings, it offers a refined, understated elegance that feels confident yet subtle—perfect when you want sophistication without standing out too much.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Old fashioned floral bar soap x Irish spring bar soap= Essenza... Soap on steroids.
For me this is too strong; almost headache inducing.
It's a nice scent, but needs to be toned down.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: The dry down is just bar soap... It's fine but come on. The opening is better. Eau sauvage is more citrusy by the way.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Screechy clean in a synthetic and abrasive way at first. it suits me better in the colder season, not for hot summer days

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Still love this stuff and the new atomizer is like the old Creed ones! Fire hydrient!!

This is Top 3 Spring frag of all time
1. GIT
2. Essenza
3. Eau Sauvage Cologne

Just ticks all the boxes, smells great like absolutely incredible though I Totally see how others wouldn't like this.

Classy, smooth, refined, vibrant, lively are just a few words to sum it up.

10/10 - For this style of perfume you can't really get better especially for the price unless you want to go for a Tom Ford even then I prefer this to NP.

9.5/10 overall only losing half a point for versatility (cold weather this dods struggle somewhat however I do love it on a crisp morning)

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The absolute pinnacle of a men's cologne. Don't be fooled by the typical 4711's blast of neroli in starting notes, because it will change completely in about 20 minutes or so. Just imagine classical Dior Eau Sauvage, but amped up on every level, while keeping its fresh and citrusy nature - that's what Colonia Essenza is about. Absolutely stunning, I'd say easily in my Top 3 men's fragrances of all times.

Btw, the perfumer of this fragrance is Michel Almairac, but he's not listed here for some reason.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: smells like hair spray. 10/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
One Word to describe this scent is "Understatement". This Smells like a gentleman, its literally class and sopistication in a bottle, it doesnt scream very loud but it stays close to my skin for a long time. Extremly versitile for the spring and summer time regardless of day or night. Overall i give it 8.5/10 , would be higher if only it projects a little bit better.

Update: Its my Signature Fragrance Now

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Italian stallion?
Dwarf Pony maybe…
It’s very mild. Clean and fresh. It won’t get you through a date, nor an evening at La Scala. But you will feel old-world crisp.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Beautiful, soapy, elegant scent. I cannot praise this enough. Smells like italian luxury. If you’re looking for a beast mode fragrance this isn’t it, but if you want a timeless classy scent, Colonia Essenza is the way to go.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
''smells like vacation!!'', first reaction i got spraying it from my sis. it smells classic, italian everything that conjures the relaxed mediterrean vibe. the initial spray of photo realistic citrus is so sparkly and airy. like a field of grape/orange trees in the wind. and the opening does last quite a while and i love that. Neroli, neroli, neroli all the way.

this is what michael corleone smelled like in part 2 when he wore his casual clothes going back to his heritage vineyard in sicily!

After the long lasting citrus opening gradually settles. a very thick soapiness comes up in the mid with beautiful floral hints of rose/jasmine + complimentary orange bitter green of petitgrain that make you feel relaxed, comfortable, clean. that soapiness persists pretty much till the end combined with a unique green herbal fougere profile of sage + rosemary with a slight minty/ camphor undertone. woody vetiver + a tinge of cloves. theres an ambiguous leather accord too. with a generous amount of earthy patchouli musk / amber warmth / oakmoss base as support making it masculine. the cloves is the secret ingredient here, working magic in the background adding a layer of complexity from base to mid.

Please judge this with the appropriate weather condition its meant for.
It's not a powerful projecting scent however it does leave scent trails that are just out of this world. it really does need a good warm outside temperature and wind. and thats often with really good natural smelling summer scents that are not relying on powerful aroma chemicals to give lift.

The opening is the most projecting part and it last like 20-30 minutes and that's bit unusual for a citrus forward frag. prob cuz of how much neroli n petitgrain is used giving an illusion of a continues citrus. within that time reception of others was lovely. after that I never really had a compliment unless im like very close to someone however when the mid develops the scent trail is just something so good that i had someone run up to me to ask what i am wearing. literally never had that happen with anything else lol. Honestly the longevity is a fair 5-6 hours. But not like it dies within the last few hours. It holds on wrapping you around a scent bubble for 4 and giving you 2 hours skin scent. letting it self known to your own nose every so often. a slight over spray works well with it.

it's not a dated scent... but its not a blind buy. the scent will wear you if you cannot appreciate the uniqueness + oldskool/modern vibe. it's not challenging at all to wear. quite safe really. and i read some people comparing this like a dollar store scent? come on.. tom ford portofino neroli which i genuinely find smelling like baby wipes with an outrageous pricetag lasting barely 1-2 hours is deserving of that label not this.

its genuinely a complex unique scent but you wouldn't be able to tell right away. it has enough transitions to discover. its one of my fave summer scent for a while. i just had to get another bottle years later. it can be worn all seasons acting like an work/office scent too. I got prada amber pour homme too and i prefer the soapiness in that one cuz of overall versatility performance / projection but sometimes you want something that doesn't announce itself but is to be discovered.

don michael corleone/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Essenza di Colonia varies depending on my body temperature. When I’m hot and sweaty, it goes directly into soapy, neroli, citrusy, aromatic territory. When I’m just sitting in an AC’ed room, it’s camphor and grapefruit, which can last a long time until we get to the soap. It reminds me an old sweater or what you put in the drawers of sweaters. Moderate sillage and longevity

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: I did not enjoy this one. The soapy, green, floral accords are not a good combo on this ole' boys skin. Like any fragrance, I can see why some folks may appreciate it. A risky blind buy IMHO.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This is pure class, elegance and sophistication (they probably all mean the same but you get my point) in a bottle. James Bond would wear this and if you like to dress up, so should you.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: In the opening it smells like a toilet citrus product. It gets better in the drydown but nothing special. Try Zegna's Italian Bergamot edp for a far superior experience.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: really good soapy citrus. i smell some leather in it. lasts long and is a good formal scent for me. got a 1,7 oz for 50 and im happy with it

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Smells amazing. But only lasts about 5hours on me. A bit overpriced. It's sad because this is a green opening that goes to soapy clean scent is really good a you can wear this for any occasion. I wish there was a Parfum version of this.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Citrus,
soapy floral,
oakmoss, earthy, and amber

Clean and fairly complex.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
This thing is so perfect, you smell like a confident beast, that is in a good and pleasant mood.

Soapy, expensive smelling, fresh and clean, a bit sweet.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: it just smells overwhelmingly of cheap unsencted soap

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Revisited this after I got in another low partial. If you like Colonia, you probably will like this. If you like Neroli, you probably will like this. This is for the more mature individuals as it has the typical Old classic citrus dna and style so younger men may find it too mature but it's still pretty modern in these days. It's neroli cirtusy classic soapy fresh that's a little older fashioned but works perfectly for the summer and sunny days.

I've loved it if the lovely opening can last longer. But for the price that's available on Full Bottles in the market, I think it's pretty good value.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Surely one of the most beautiful fragrances ever made and the best Acqua di Parma...

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The opening is not bad, but the dry down is so good. It's about super luxury soap,it's not like cheap one at Prada l'homme,it's more deep, masculine and a little bit sweet. Also lasts incredibly long on my skin,especially for the freshie,did two sprays and i can still smell it,it's been like 8 hours ago,and I even took a shower and it's still here. Prada l'homme about synthetic cheap soap and this is the reverse of that. So good,definitely one of my favorites
smell:10/10 (let it dry down trust me)
opening: 5/10 not a big fan
dry down : 10/10
sillage: 6/10
projection: 5,5/10
longevity: 9/10
overall 10/10

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
The citrus, which is nice, and of good quality, lasts for literally 2 minutes on me then I'm overwhelmed by an almost carbolic soap smell for the next 4 hours. I like it. Prada Amber is still the undisputed soap king. I'll persevere in my quest to find a worthy advesary for the Prada.

Edit. Been wearing this for a few days now, and it's a grower. The soapiness is sharp. Very. But it smells tremendous. In a modern world of sweet androgynous scents, this is a kiss my ass to them all. I can't see this being for everyone, the original Colonia may fit that bill a little better, but this is stellar stuff. Backup bottle worthy.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: This goes from a green opening to a soap clean scent. it's a great everyday signature scent because there's never a place where this isn't appropriate to wear.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: Patchouli is the star here, smells like a hippie won the mega millions and soaped up at the Waldorf Astoria.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content: people think that while neroli + bergamot scents will make them old, juvenile sweet scents will make them appear younger. well, sillier probably, but younger? i doubt.

product_name: Essenza di Colonia Acqua di Parma
review_content:
Well shoot- this just did not work for my skin at this point in time (I'm 59). I might try it again...when I'm like 85!!!
Blind buy at your own peril!
